title: Wedding Belt
provenience: China | Guizhou Province | Taijiang County | Shidong Town | Tanglong Village
creator: Tongying Wu's Mother
description: Belt.  Part of wedding outfit.  Embroidered strip of cloth of pink, red, blue, white, orange, green native provincial made silk.  Woven geometric pattern.  Tassles at each end.  Made by Tonying Wu's mother.
credit_line: Purchased from Tongying Wu, 1997

title: Pants
provenience: China | Guizhou Province | Taijiang County | Shidong Town | Tanglong Village
creator: Tongying Wu
description: Pants worn with wedding outfit.  Indigo dyed.  Stiff, leathery, shiny cloth.  Indigo cotton waistband.
credit_line: Purchased from Tongying Wu, 1997

title: Cartoon
description: Cartoon for a painting made by wood block print on coarse native paper.  Probably printed in Derge.  Image of a high lama incarnation on a lotus throne.
credit_line: Gift of Schuyler V. R. Cammann, 1951

title: Wedding Jacket
provenience: China | Guizhou Province | Youngjiang County | Shidong Town | Tanglong Village
creator: Tongying Wu
description: Wedding jacket made and worn by Tongying Wu, Miao textile artist. These jackets were worn for weddings and then later for special occasions. Black cotton with elaborately embroidered strips on neckline and shoulders. Bright colors, especially red. Embroidered images of people, serpents, bats, elephants, and other animals. Cloth is stiff. Native provincial made cotton and silk.
credit_line: Purchased from Tongying Wu, 1997

title: Wedding Apron
provenience: China | Guizhou Province | Youngjiang County | Shidong Town | Tanglong Village
creator: Tongying Wu
description: Wedding apron or skirt made and worn by Tongying Wu, Miao textile artist.  These aprons were worn for weddings and then later for special occasions.  Rectangular apron made of four strips of cloth sewn together:  top indigo stiff material; central embroidered white cotton panel with fringe; and two blue silk embroidered side panels. Bright colors, with alot of red.  Embroidered images of dog/lion, people, butterflies, a half-human/half-serpent, goldfish, bats and serpents or snakes on central panel.  Side panels with flowers, phoenixes and other small rodents.  Native provincial hand woven cotton and silk.
credit_line: Purchased from Tongying Wu, 1997

title: Oracle Bone
description: Fragment of bone with ancient Chinese characters inscribed on it.  Said to be one of a collection of oracle bones obtained by Langdon Warner in 1913-14 at the village of Xiaotun at the site of Anyang. Shang Dynasty kings used oracle bones as a form of divination to seek supernatural guidance about important political, social, and personal issues. Usually created from cattle shoulder blades and the underside of turtle shells, the bones were smoothed and then heated until they cracked. By interpreting the cracks, royal diviners believed they were receiving insight that allowed them to answer questions about the future. In many cases, a record of the reading was written on the bones. These texts provide invaluable information about early Chinese religion, politics, and elite life.
credit_line: Exchange with Peabody Museum, Harvard, 1955

title: Interleaf Pad
provenience: China | Beijing | Taimiao | Temple of Ancestors
description: Small rectangular cloth pad of yellow silk brocade with floral motif in gold thread.  One of five pads to be placed between the jade pages of 79-23-1A-J.
credit_line: Gift of Smedley D. Butler, Jr., Thomas R. Butler, Edith M. P. Wehle and Philippa Wehle Chill, 1979

title: Book Wrapper
provenience: China | Beijing | Taimiao | Temple of Ancestors
description: Square cloth wrapper of patches of yellow cloth with printed gold designs of circular medallion with dragon at center and four corner motifs.  Backing is plain yellow silk.  At one corner a tie of yellow silk with gold thread brocade approximately 114 cm in length and 3.5 cm in width is attached.
credit_line: Gift of Smedley D. Butler, Jr., Thomas R. Butler, Edith M. P. Wehle and Philippa Wehle Chill, 1979

title: Box
provenience: China | Beijing | Taimiao | Temple of Ancestors
description: Box for storage of jade tablets.  Gilded with molded decoration of dragons on exterior.
credit_line: Gift of Smedley D. Butler, Jr., Thomas R. Butler, Edith M. P. Wehle and Philippa Wehle Chill, 1979

title: Arrow Head
description: Arrow head.  Iron.  Point with triangular sections; long shank somewhat squared.  Corroded and bent.  Obtained at Hongqiao Pass through the Great Wall.
credit_line: Gift of William C. Watts, 1935

title: Book Wrapper
provenience: China | Beijing | Taimiao | Temple of Ancestors
description: Square cloth wrapper made up of irregular sized patches of yellow silk brocade with cloud motif and printed gold designs of circular medallion with dragon at center, four smaller circular medallions and four corner motifs. Backing is plain yellow silk. Rust stains and holes especially on backing.
credit_line: Gift of Smedley D. Butler, Jr., Thomas R. Butler, Edith M. P. Wehle and Philippa Wehle Chill, 1979

title: Tile
description: Yellow glazed pottery terminal tile.
credit_line: Gift of George L. Farnum and John Edward Farnum, 1898

title: Death Mask
description: The delicate features of this thin silver death mask were beaten into shape from a heavy sheet of metal. Masks like this were placed over the faces of men and women of the Kitan (Qidan) tribes that formed the Liao empire. The masks were attached to gold, silver, or copper wire shrouds that covered the buried bodies of the Kitan and were buried in Inner Mongolia and Liaoning Province from the mid-10th to early 12th century CE.   The eyes are partly closed with heavy eyebrows and a long thin nose. There is a small mouth and long ears, each with a pierced hole in the lobe.
credit_line: Purchased from Mathias Komor, 1944

title: Mirror
description: Bronze mirror with band of dragons. Fine smooth lacquer-like green patina. In fitted box.
credit_line: Purchased from Mathias Komor, 1954

title: Printing Block
description: Wooden printing block.  With Tibetan script.  Probably made in Beijing.  Chinese characters on end. Text on both sides.
credit_line: Gift of Pennsylvania Historical and Museum Commission, 1949

title: Lottery Book
description: Square sheet of paper printed with the first 80 characters of the Thousand Character Classic in vertical columns inside a square border, and marked up with brush and red ink. A horizontal line of text reading zhao lai yuan di gei 照來原底給 runs through the middle of the square. To this is added a company name stamp 泰記厰, and a brush-written time, 十夜. These cards were used to play the gambling game of pok kop piu (Mandarin: bai ge piao 白鴿票,"white pigeon lottery"). The aim was to guess correctly twenty characters selected at random from the opening eighty of the Thousand-Character Classic. The game was widely played in Canton, and in overseas Chinese communities. It continues to be played in Macao today under the Portuguese spelling "pacapio" and in US casinos under the name "keno", with numbers 1-80 in place of the original Chinese characters.
credit_line: Gift of Maxwell Sommerville, 1895

title: Lottery Book
description: Nine square sheets of paper glued together and printed with the first 80 characters of the Thousand Character Classic in vertical columns inside a square border, and marked up with brush and red ink. A horizontal line of text  zhao lai yuan di gei 照來原底給 runs through the middle of the square. To this is added a company name stamp 德利厰, and a brush-written time,十九日. These cards were used to play the gambling game of pok kop piu (Mandarin: bai ge piao 白鴿票,"white pigeon lottery"). The aim was to guess correctly twenty characters selected at random from the opening eighty of the Thousand-Character Classic. The game was widely played in Canton, and in overseas Chinese communities. It continues to be played in Macao today under the Portuguese spelling "pacapio" and in US casinos under the name "keno", with numbers 1-80 in place of the original Chinese characters. Green printing on thin white paper. Red brush strokes.
credit_line: Gift of Maxwell Sommerville, 1895

title: Lottery Book
description: Two square sheets of paper glued together and printed with the first 80 characters of the Thousand Character Classic in vertical columns inside a square border, and marked up with brush and red ink. These cards were used to play the gambling game of pok kop piu (Mandarin: bai ge piao 白鴿票,"white pigeon lottery"). title: Lottery Book
description: Square sheet of paper glued together and printed with the first 80 characters of the Thousand Character Classic in vertical columns inside a square border, and marked up with brush and red ink. A horizontal line of text zhao lai yuan di gei wen tai zao 照來原底給文泰造  runs through the middle of the square. To this is added a company name stamp 恆和厰 and a brush-written time, 十六日. The company name is stamped on the top and reads: Hang Wo & Co.   To the left it reads: Day Time. These cards were used to play the gambling game of pok kop piu (Mandarin: bai ge piao 白鴿票,"white pigeon lottery"). The aim was to guess correctly twenty characters selected at random from the opening eighty of the Thousand-Character Classic. The game was widely played in Canton, and in overseas Chinese communities. It continues to be played in Macao today under the Portuguese spelling "pacapio" and in US casinos under the name "keno", with numbers 1-80 in place of the original Chinese characters.
credit_line: Gift of Maxwell Sommerville, 1895

title: Book
provenience: China | Beijing | Taimiao | Temple of Ancestors
materials: Nephrite | Silk | Gold | Lapis Lazuli | Gold Thread
description: One page in book made of ten green nephrite slabs which are pierced and strung together with gold cord.  Cover of yellow silk with gold brocade cloud design with symbols sewn to fit tablets.  Edict written in 1648 in which Emperor Fu-lin confers a posthumous honorary title of Empress on his great-great-great-grandmother, a Manchurian tribeswoman.  End panels form the covers of the book each with incised pair of dragons and a flaming pearl.  Incised lines of dragons and script with gold dust in incisions and proper names filled in with lapis lazuli.  Written in both Chinese and Manchu Running Script, beginning at opposite ends and ending at center.  Interleaving pads and wrappings assigned suffixes K-R.
credit_line: Gift of Smedley D. Butler, Jr., Thomas R. Butler, Edith M. P. Wehle and Philippa Wehle Chill, 1979

title: Book
provenience: China | Beijing | Taimiao | Temple of Ancestors
materials: Nephrite | Silk | Gold | Lapis Lazuli | Gold Thread

These cards were used to play the gambling game of pok kop piu (Mandarin: bai ge piao 白鴿票,"white pigeon lottery"). The aim was to guess correctly twenty characters selected at random from the opening eighty of the Thousand-Character Classic. The game was widely played in Canton, and in overseas Chinese communities. It continues to be played in Macao today under the Portuguese spelling "pacapio" and in US casinos under the name "keno", with numbers 1-80 in place of the original Chinese characters.
credit_line: Gift of Maxwell Sommerville, 1895

title: Lottery Book
creator: Unknown
description: Six square sheets of paper glued together and printed with the first 80 characters of the Thousand Character Classic in vertical columns inside a square border, and marked up with brush and red ink. A horizontal line of text zhao lai yuan di gei wen tai zao 照來原底給文泰造  runs through the middle of the square. To this is added a company name stamp 利記厰, and a brush-written time, 十三. The company name is stamped on the top and reads: Lee Kee Co. below it says: Night Time. These cards were used to play the gambling game of pok kop piu also known as pakapoo (Mandarin: bai ge piao 白鴿票,"white pigeon lottery"). The aim was to guess correctly twenty characters selected at random from the opening eighty of the Thousand-Character Classic. The game was widely played in Canton, and in overseas Chinese communities. It continues to be played in Macao today under the Portuguese spelling "pacapio" and in US casinos under the name "keno", with numbers 1-80 in place of the original Chinese characters.
credit_line: Gift of Maxwell Sommerville, 1895

title: Mirror
description: Bronze mirror.  Intricate design of dragons and modified TLV decoration.  Four character inscription.  Green patina.  Has been repaired. Broken into 2 pieces.
credit_line: Purchased from Mathias Komor, 1954

title: Book
provenience: China | Beijing | Taimiao | Temple of Ancestors
materials: Nephrite | Silk | Gold | Lapis Lazuli | Gold Thread
description: One page in book made of ten green nephrite slabs which are pierced and strung together with gold cord.  Cover of yellow silk with gold brocade cloud design with symbols sewn to fit tablets.  Edict written in 1648 in which Emperor Fu-lin confers a posthumous honorary title of Empress on his great-great-great-grandmother, a Manchurian tribeswoman.  End panels form the covers of the book each with incised pair of dragons and a flaming pearl.  Incised lines of dragons and script with gold dust in incisions and proper names filled in with lapis lazuli.  Written in both Chinese and Manchu Running Script, beginning at opposite ends and ending at center.  Interleaving pads and wrappings assigned suffixes K-R.
credit_line: Gift of Smedley D. Butler, Jr., Thomas R. Butler, Edith M. P. Wehle and Philippa Wehle Chill, 1979

title: Tile
description: Glazed yellow tile.  Surmounted with lion.
credit_line: Gift of George L. Farnum and John Edward Farnum, 1898

title: Ceremonial Jacket
creator: Tongying Wu's Mother
description: Child's ceremonial jacket.  Worn by Tonying Wu, Miao artist/embroiderer, when she was 3 years old.  Black silk with elaborately embroidered collar, cuffs and decorative pieces at bottom edge.  Woven strip along bottom edge.  Interior lined with blue cotton.  Metallic thread, beads and tassels were used from mother's generation to present and tassels may have been added to this jacket before she was born.
credit_line: Purchased from Tongying Wu, 1997

title: Cartoon
description: Fragment of a cartoon for a painting.  Printed with wood blocks.  Probably printed in Derge.  On coarse native paper.  Bhaisajyaguru, Buddha of Medicine.
credit_line: Gift of Schuyler V. R. Cammann, 1951

title: Wedding Jacket
creator: Tongying Wu's Great Grandmother
description: Wedding jacket made by great grandmother of Tongying Wu, Miao textile artist.  These jackets were worn for weddings and then later for special occasions.  Black patterned cotton with elaborately embroidered and woven strips on neckline, shoulders and sleeves.  Flying dragon embroidered design on red silk patch on sleeves.  Sequins and gold foil.  Borders with triangular folded silk design.  Interior blue lining.  Native provincial hand woven cotton and silk.
credit_line: Purchased from Tongying Wu, 1997

title: Reproduction
description: Copy of one of the slabs from the Wu Liang Mausoleum built in 147 CE during the Han Dynasty by the Wu family in the present Jiaxiang County, Department of Jining, Shandong Province.  Also known as the Wu family shrine. Hard black stone, the background cut away in little rough grooves, now weathered grey, so that the figures stand out like silhouettes.  Three registers with historical and legendary scenes. Lower panel: Fu Xi and Nu Wa, mythical founders of China's polity, with attendant sprites. Middle panel: attempted assassination of Qin Shi Huang, builder of the Great Wall. Upper panel: "Strong man" of Chinese history protecting his wounded lord with chariot canopy. One of five pieces.
credit_line: Purchased from C. T. Loo, 1916

title: Reproduction
description: Copy of one of the slabs from the Wu Liang Mausoleum built in 147 CE during the Han Dynasty by the Wu family in the present Jiaxiang County, Department of Jining, Shandong Province. title: Jacket Panel
creator: Tongying Wu's Mother
description: Man's jacket back panel.  Made by mother of Tongying Wu, Miao textile artist.  Black square panel with strips of elaborately decorated and embroidered panels on one side.  Diamond shaped panel at center.  Serpents and butterflies in design.  Gold foil and sequins.
credit_line: Purchased from Tongying Wu, 1997

title: Rupee
description: Obv. Portrait of Emperor Guangxu (光緒).  Rev. 四川省造 Sichuan sheng zao (Made in Sichuan Province). Silver rupee cast in Sichuan Province for use in Tibet. These are modeled on British rupees with the portrait of Queen Victoria made for use in India.
credit_line: Gift of Mrs. Robert R. Service, 1951

title: Jacket Panel
creator: Tongying Wu's Mother
description: Woman's jacket back panel.  Made by mother of Tongying Wu, Miao textile artist.  Black square panel with strips of elaborately decorated and embroidered panels on one side.  Diamond shaped panel at center with trefoil pieces in four corners.  Serpents and butterflies in design.  Gold foil and sequins.
credit_line: Purchased from Tongying Wu, 1997

title: Rupee
description: Obv. Portrait of Emperor Guangxu (光緒).  Rev. 四川省造 Sichuan sheng zao (Made in Sichuan Province). Silver rupee cast in Sichuan Province for use in Tibet.These are modeled on British rupees with the portrait of Queen Victoria made for use in India. Pierced as ornament so is useless as coin.
credit_line: Gift of Mrs. Robert R. Service, 1951

title: Censer Lid
description: Lid for bronze incense burner (39-27-1A).  The cover is in the form of a 'hill' with figures of various animals depicted on the ledges, below which are slits to emit the fumes of the incense.  This 'hill' design is supposed to represent one of the three Isles of the Blest, Penglai, where existed the drug that prevented death.
credit_line: Purchased from Leon F. S. Stark, 1939

title: Wedding Jacket
creator: Tongying Wu's Grandmother
description: Wedding jacket made by grandmother of Tongying Wu, Miao textile artist.  These jackets were worn for weddings and then later for special occasions.  Black cotton with elaborately embroidered and woven strips on neckline, front border, shoulders and sleeves.  Dragon and bird design on black silk on sleeves.  Sequins and gold foil.  Woven border on front edge.  Triangular folded silk design.  Interior cotton blue lining.  Native provincial hand woven cotton and silk.
credit_line: Purchased from Tongying Wu, 1997

title: Statuette
description: Gilt bronze statuette of Guanyin.  Tall graceful figure standing holding lotus bud in hands.  Over the forehead at the base of the high crown headdress is a tiny figure of the Amida Buddha.  When acquired, the statue was covered with a thick emerald green patina except for the hands, face and throat which retained their smooth gilding; there were traces of gold on the garments.  The statue has since been cleaned.  Found in a river near the Aipao village which was the ancient seat of the Jianning Monastery; the village is a suburb of Liaoyang, south of Shenyang in Liaoning Province.
credit_line: Purchased from C. T. Loo; Subscription of Mrs. Emory R. Johnson, 1921

title: Thangka
description: Very old Tibetan painting.  Padmasambhava (Tibetan: pema jung ne. English: the Lotus Born): from the land of Oddiyana, Padmasambhava is considered one of the three principal founders of Tibetan Buddhism in the 8th century. Founder of the Red Lama sect, with Vajrapani, demon form, below. Inscription on back.
credit_line: Gift of Schuyler V. R. Cammann, 1951

title: Wedding Jacket
creator: Tongying Wu's Mother
description: Wedding jacket made by mother of Tongying Wu, Miao textile artist.  These jackets were worn for weddings and then later for special occasions.  Black cotton with elaborately woven strips on back, neckline, hem and shoulders.  Mosquitos and butterflies on border at top.  Beetles in border down center of back.  7 Shou, or longevity symbols on back.  Bats in lower hem.  Borders with felt and wax resist dyed cotton.  Interior cotton blue lining.  Native provincial hand woven cotton and silk.
credit_line: Purchased from Tongying Wu, 1997

title: Censer
description: Bronze incense burner, boshanlu (博山爐).  A figure of a phoenix standing on the back of a tortoise supports the bowl, the cover (39-27-1B) of which is in the form of a 'hill' with figures of various animals depicted on the ledges, below which are slits to emit the fumes of the incense.  This 'hill' design is supposed to represent one of the three Isles of the Blest, Penglai, where existed the drug that prevented death.
credit_line: Purchased from Leon F. S. Stark, 1939

title: Thangka
description: Painting.  Dorje Setrab, a Tibetan warrior god with six attendants.  Top:  Tsongkhapa, an unidentified high lama, and Vajrabhairava.
credit_line: Gift of Schuyler V. R. Cammann, 1951

title: Playing Card Deck
description: One of two sets of playing cards, used to play Luk Fu 六虎 ( Six Tigers). Called lat chi/ lut chi (甩紙) or lieh ch'ih (廢紙) by Stewart Culin and W.H. Wilkinson who collected them. There are 40 different cards. All the cards are inscribed with their value in large stylized characters at the top. Of these there are 35 cards in four suits: 2 to 9 of shi  拾 (tens [of strings of 1000 cash]), 1-9 of guan 貫 (strings of 1000 cash), 1-9 of suo 索 (strings of 100 cash), and 1-9 of qian 錢 (cash). The 1 of cash has the name yun qian 雲綫 (cloud money or Yunnan coin). In addition there are five extra cards with the names lu hua 鹿花, bai zi 百子 (hundred sons), mao gong 毛公 (prince of Mao), qian zi 千子(thousand sons) and wan zi 萬子 (ten thousand sons). Red underprints are on 8 of shi, 9's of shi, guan and suo, and on Mao gong, bai zi, qian zi, and wan zi. These read: 謝家英豐齋, 仁記錢貫索. The backs are black.
credit_line: Purchased from William Henry Wilkinson, 1903

title: Statue Base
description: This carved pedestal of dark grey limestone would have originally supported a statue in the socket at the top. The pedestal depicts scenes from one of the Jataka Tales, stories describing one of many previous incarnations of the Buddha before he was born as Siddhartha Gautama, or Sakyamuni. In this incarnation, the Buddha had been born as Prince Vessantara who gives away his worldly possessions, including an elephant thought to ensure wealth of his kingdom. This unprecedented generosity leads to his eventual attainment of enlightenment. The front panel shows an earth deity accompanied by lokapalas, or guardians. On the left Vessantara gives away his last belongings, including his cart. He says goodbye to his children on the right side, with his wife shown detained by deities in the form of wild animals so that she will not witneess Vessantara parting from their children. The back panel depicts Vessantara's two children now as servants in the hills.
credit_line: Purchased from C. T. Loo; Randall Morgan Fund, 1934

title: Wedding Apron
creator: Tongying Wu's Mother
description: Wedding apron, or skirt, made and worn by mother of Tongying Wu, Miao textile artist.  These aprons were worn for weddings and then later for special occasions.  Indigo cotton waist panel with ties and 9 hanging panels.  At the end of each panel are seed beads and white feathers stitched in place with a small red triangular piece of cloth.  Elaborately embroidered panels on silk in the following designs:  flowers and pomegranates; vines; butterflies and flowers; snails; flat fish, leaves and central flower; crabs with grass and flower.  Native provincial hand woven cotton and silk.
credit_line: Purchased from Tongying Wu, 1997

title: Thangka
description: Painting.  Very rare dancing form of Avalokitesvara (Lokeshvara).  Top:  Sakyamuni, Tsongkhapa, and a bodhisattva, Hayagriva and Mahakala.  At sides:  Ushnishavijaya and a rare form of Shiva or an ascetic.  Bottom:  three rare forms of Avalokitsvara, including the Simhasana one.  Fine Sichuan silks in mounting. There is an inscription on the back.
credit_line: Gift of Schuyler V. R. Cammann, 1951

title: Cake Mold
description: Rice cake mold. Light colored wood block with handle, carved with concave peach design and character for longevity – shou壽 – in the center. Stamped Chinese text in red below the design: Zhongguo Mianhu guo yin中国棉湖粿印 “Rice cake mold, Mianhu, China.” Mianhu is a town in the Chaoshan region of Guangdong Province. Molds like these are used to make a local variety of stuffed rice cake – hongtaoguo 红桃粿 “red peach cakes” – particularly for festivals like Lunar New Year.
credit_line: Gift of the Estate of Elizabeth Lyons, Keeper of the Asian Collections, University Museum, 1989

title: Scoop
description: Made from thick plant fibers, bundled together to form the handle and the bowl.

credit_line: Gift of Mrs. Cummins Catherwood, Jr., 1975

title: Puzzle
description: Nine rods and strings puzzle. The object is to tangle the strings and then untangle them. They can also be used as a braiding tool by twisting them in different configurations.
credit_line: Gift of Elizabeth W. Bonsall and Mary W. Bonsall, 1927

credit_line: Gift of the Philadelphia Commercial Museum (also known as the Philadelphia Civic Center Museum), Philadelphia, Pennsylvania, 2003

title: Puzzle

credit_line: Gift of Elizabeth W. Bonsall and Mary W. Bonsall, 1927

title: Sleeve
description: One of a pair of sleeves.  Blue and white batik on very fine, homespun cotton.  Geometric, curly queue design.  Ends of strip of cloth sewn together to form sleeve tube.  One end is hemmed, other is left unfinished.
credit_line: Gift of Mr. and Mrs. Robert M. Baylis, 1998

title: Sleeve
description: One of a pair of sleeves.  Blue and white batik on very fine, homespun cotton.  Geometric, curly queue design.  Ends of strip of cloth sewn together to form sleeve tube.  One end is hemmed, other is left unfinished.
credit_line: Gift of Mr. and Mrs. Robert M. Baylis, 1998

title: Painting
description: Black watercolor on white paper. Depicts motifs from Han dynasty era stone slabs from Qufu in Shandong province. This ink painting may have been done by Anneliese Gutkind-Bulling based on illustrations in her book "The Meaning of China's Most Ancient Art".
credit_line: Gift of Anneliese Gutkind-Bulling, 1985

title: Playing Card Deck
description: Playing card deck used to play Tian Jiu, 天九, or Heavens and Nines. Rectangular cards with rounded corners.  Backs have printed hexagonal and diamond motif.  Faces have black and red spot on white background.  Between the dots is blank or with motif printed in color.  13 of the cards with a pair of butterflies facing a central circle with additional black and red dots.  Eight of the cards have a pair of dots facing a central circle with black and red dots. 48 of the cards have a single seated or standing figure with an object in hand such as a fan, musical instrument, manuscript, cloth, lotus.  Chinese characters written beside figure. There are two and sometimes three cards with identical figures.The jokers, identified by their lack of pips, read: 姚桂卿 Yao Guiqing , 龍大少 Long dashao (Master Long), 阿采 Ah-Cai, 潘大少 Pan dashao (Master Pan), 完姐  Wan jie (Elder Sister Wan), 萬大少 Wan dashao (Master Wan).
credit_line: Purchased from William Henry Wilkinson, 1903

title: Wedding Dress
description: Wedding dress made for and worn by JiLin Wu (1918-2002) for her 1943 wedding in Changdu, Sichuan, China.  Sleeveless red silk with green, yellow, orange and cream floral embroidery around hem, side slits, neck, collar, and arms.
credit_line: Gift of Dr. Mimi Keating in memory of JiLin Wu 吴吉臨, 2012

title: Talisman
description: Printed exorcistic charm or talisman known as bai jie zhi百解紙 (“hundred removals paper”) or bai jie fu 百解符 (“hundred removals talisman”). Printed to a standard design and text, these paper talismans are used in Chinese popular religion (sometimes called “Daoism”) to remove troubles and misfortunes. There are images of three deities, and text describing the efficacy claimed for the talisman. Blanks are left for the users to fill in their date of birth and identifying details. The talisman is burnt in order to take effect. They are very cheaply printed as much of the printing has faded and become difficult to read. The most common concept in the text is that of jie 解 “to remove, resolve, release, exorcise". The paper charm bears a red sealing, with the text fo fa seng bao 佛法僧寶 “The Treasures: Buddha, Dharma, Sanga.” The rest of the legible text includes the following:
credit_line: Bequest of Maxwell Sommerville, 1904

title: Scarf
description: Delicate gauze 'visiting' scarf, or Hada, with fringed ends. Beige color. In poor condition with several tears. Poor quality. Hadas were used by Tibetans on important occasions such as weddings and funerals as precious presents. Their white color symbolizes purity and sincerity.

title: Talisman
description: Printed exorcistic charm or talisman known as bai jie zhi百解紙 (“hundred removals paper”) or bai jie fu 百解符 (“hundred removals talisman”). Printed to a standard design and text, these paper talismans are used in Chinese popular religion (sometimes called “Daoism”) to remove troubles and misfortunes. There are images of three deities, and text describing the efficacy claimed for the talisman. Blanks are left for the users to fill in their date of birth and identifying details. The talisman is burnt in order to take effect. They are very cheaply printed as much of the printing has faded and become difficult to read. The most common concept in the text is that of jie 解 “to remove, resolve, release, exorcise". The paper charm bears a red sealing, with the text fo fa seng bao 佛法僧寶 “The Treasures: Buddha, Dharma, Sanga.” The rest of the legible text includes the following:
credit_line: Bequest of Maxwell Sommerville, 1904

title: Rubbing
description: Spiraling serpants, original from Teng County, Shandong. Black ink on rice paper. From Han tomb reliefs. Heavier paper.
credit_line: Gift of Anneliese Gutkind-Bulling, 1985

title: Rubbing
description: Rubbing of the inscription on the back of C284 with Commentary by Duanfang, 端方 (1861 - 1911).
credit_line: Purchased from C. T. Loo, 1918

title: Rubbing
description: Xiwangmu figure below, original from Teng County, Shandong. Black ink on rice paper. From Han tomb reliefs. Heavier paper.
credit_line: Gift of Anneliese Gutkind-Bulling, 1985

title: Rubbing
description: Chariots and kneeling figures, original from Teng County, Shandong. Black ink on rice paper. From Han tomb reliefs. Heavier paper.

title: Rubbing
description: Four registers with chariots, original from Teng County, Shandong. Black ink on rice paper. From Han tomb reliefs. Heavier paper.

title: Rubbing
description: Two Bi, original from Teng County, Shandong. Black ink on rice paper. From Han tomb reliefs. Heavier paper. Geometric design.
credit_line: Gift of Anneliese Gutkind-Bulling, 1985

title: Painting
description: Black watercolor on white paper. House scene based on a rubbing from Teng County in Shandong province. Square cut from right center bottom.
credit_line: Gift of Anneliese Gutkind-Bulling, 1985

title: Rubbing
description: Four registers with Xiwangmu at the top. From Teng County, Shandong. Black ink on rice paper. From Han tomb reliefs. Heavier paper.
credit_line: Gift of Anneliese Gutkind-Bulling, 1985

title: Playing Card Deck
description: Deck of playing cards based on dominoes.  84 cards in total, four each of the standard 21 examples.
credit_line: Gift of R. Stewart Culin, 1898

title: Coin
description: Obv. 康熙通寶 Kang Xi Tong Bao. Rev. Tai left, 臺 Tai right. Mint: Taiwan. 1689 - 1692 CE.
credit_line: Purchased from Rev. Edward W. Thwing; subscription of Robert C. H. Brock, 1902

title: Pigeon Whistle
description: Ko-tze.  Attached to tail of carrier pigeon. Bamboo, black, 2 cylinder, small bamboo tube insert in each
credit_line: Gift of the Philadelphia Museum of Art, 1951

title: Coin
description: Obv. 康熙通寶 Kang Xi Tong Bao. Rev. Tai left, 臺 Tai right. Mint: Taiwan. 1689 - 1692 CE.
credit_line: Purchased from Rev. Edward W. Thwing; subscription of Robert C. H. Brock, 1902

title: Coin
description: Obv. 廣東省造 ( Guangdong Province)  光 緒元寶 (Guangxu Coinage)  庫平七分二釐 (7.2 Candareens).  Rev. KWANG-TUNG PROVINCE 7.2 CANDAREENS with Dragon.
credit_line: Purchased from Rev. Edward W. Thwing; subscription of Robert C. H. Brock, 1902

title: Coin
description: Obv. 福建省造 (Fujian Province)  光 緒元寶 (Guangxu Coinage)  庫平七分二釐 (7.2 Candareens). Rev. FOO-KIEN PROVINCE 7.2 CANDAREENS with Dragon.
credit_line: Purchased from Rev. Edward W. Thwing; subscription of Robert C. H. Brock, 1902

title: Shuttlecock
provenience: China | Guangzhou | New York | New York City
description: About 90 circles of paper piled tightly together and speared by 3 feathers, what looks like snakeskin folded over and attached to bottom other end from feathers.
credit_line: Gift of R. Stewart Culin, 1898

title: Coin
description: Obv.廣東省造 (Guangdong Province)  光緒元寶 (Guangxu Coinage) 库平三分六釐 (3.6 Candareens). Rev. KWANG-TUNG PROVINCE 3.6 CANDAREENS with Dragon. Denomination: 5 cents.
credit_line: Purchased from Rev. Edward W. Thwing; subscription of Robert C. H. Brock, 1902

title: Pigeon Whistle
description: Pao-ti / Ko-tze / Ko-ling.  Gourd whistle attached to tails of a carrier pigeon.  Black design on yellowish gourd.
credit_line: Gift of the Philadelphia Museum of Art, 1951

title: Game Box
description: Black lacquered box of Chinese games and puzzles made of ivory with the initials J.B on the cover for Joshua Bishop. A booklet is included for tangrams.
credit_line: Gift of Elizabeth W. Bonsall and Mary W. Bonsall, 1927

title: Hand Warmer
description: Base of a small, personal hand warmer. Round base, straight sides with sloping top.
credit_line: Gift of the Philadelphia Commercial Museum (also known as the Philadelphia Civic Center Museum), Philadelphia, Pennsylvania, 2010

title: Shoe
creator: Huang Baozhen
description: One of a pair of shoes for bound feet - made and worn by Huang Baozhen (1883-1966). Silk with embroidery. Red ground with pale green edging.
credit_line: Gift of Elizabeth and Willie Liu in memory of JiLin Wu  吴吉臨, 2012

title: Shoe
creator: Huang Baozhen
description: One of a pair of shoes for bound feet - made and worn by Huang Baozhen (1883-1966). Silk with embroidery. Red ground with pale green edging.
credit_line: Gift of Elizabeth and Willie Liu in memory of JiLin Wu  吴吉臨, 2012

title: Game Box Lid
description: Black lacquered lid to a box of Chinese games and puzzles made of ivory with the initials J.B on the cover for Joshua Bishop. A booklet is included for tangrams.
credit_line: Gift of Elizabeth W. Bonsall and Mary W. Bonsall, 1927

title: Cup
description: Large ring base, bottom rounded to vertical sides. "Temmoku" or Jian ware; brown to blue glaze interior and exterior except rim edge and foot. Two characters written on the bottom.
credit_line: Bequest of Julia Morgan through brother Hugh Morgan, 1949

title: Rubbing
description: This inscription contains the date of the tomb, its dimensions, and records the name of the occupant as Zhou Dai (周代). From Tomb 52 of Region 3, Xiaoba, Leshan. Dated to February 15, 149 CE. Black ink on rice paper. From Han tomb reliefs. Heavier paper.
credit_line: Gift of Anneliese Gutkind-Bulling, 1985

title: Printing Block
description: Wooden printing block. Symbol of the ten stacked syllables of the Kalachakra (Tibetan: nam chu wang den) atop a lotus flower base. The top depicts a crescent moon and solar dot with a flame against a background of clouds.  There is text at the very bottom and flanking the center symbol.
credit_line: Purchased from Alexander Scott, 1914

title: Shoe
description: Shoe for bound foot. Tall upper with bands of different designs, lowest design is pink ground with instep and floral designs. Middle band is geometrics and stylized flowers in blue and black. Top band is painted flowers. Small tassels at the front. There is a label in German on the sole.
credit_line: Gift of the Philadelphia Commercial Museum (also known as the Philadelphia Civic Center Museum), Philadelphia, Pennsylvania, 2003

title: Cover Tile
description: Round outer face, only, of an antefix for a cover tile from the roof of a building. The tile has a raised flat margin all round inside of which is a low relief Ming dragon. The mold could be as early as 15th century, but the piece could have been cast later. The yellow glaze implies the tile was made for an Imperial building.
credit_line: Gift of Mrs. Rees H. Barkalow, 1964

title: Statue
description: Stone fu lion.  Weathered grey limestone.  Companion to C432 and similar to it but the legs are shorter, the chest broader and lower and the neck not so much arched. The ears are laid back with the spirit of ferocity not quite so well expressed. Originally part of a pair, this lion would have been placed along the entrance to a tomb as a guardian or as a protector at the gate of a temple.
credit_line: Purchased from C. T. Loo, 1924

title: Screen
description: Chinese bamboo screen with four registers. The top register contains a woman sitting with one shoe removed by a table with a vase surrounded by a floral border. Below that there are ten stylized Chinese characters with a border of bats, fish, flowers, and fruit. Below that is a butterfly surrounded by fruits and flowers. The bottom register contains a vase with a flower coming out of it and a dragonfly on the left surrounded by a floral border.  It is one of three screens.
credit_line: Purchased from / at the World's Columbian Exposition, 1893

title: Screen
description: Chinese bamboo screen with four registers. The top register contains a woman sitting and about to remove a shoe by a table with a vase holding a flower. The image is surrounded by a floral border. Below that there are ten stylized Chinese characters with a border of bats, fish, flowers, and fruit. Below that is a butterfly surrounded by fruits and flowers. The bottom register contains a vase with a flower coming out of it and an animal looking up at it surrounded by a floral border. It is one of three screens.
credit_line: Purchased from / at the World's Columbian Exposition, 1893

title: Hat
description: Women's hat. Upright brim of black otter fur. Crown of royal blue silk ornamented with gold braid forming the shou sign (long life) with swastikas; together they mean "May you live ten thousand years."  Knot of red silk cord at top. Peacock feather. Two long streamers of the blue silk with silk and metal thread embroidery including the bat and the jade music stone, both also symbols of long life.  The peacock feather is in a black box which keeps the crown in shape; the whole hat is in a box covered with flowered green silk brocade.
credit_line: Gift of Miss C. F. Bieber, 1953

title: Grave Urn Lid
description: Made in two sections: an ovoid pot with a tall ridged neck and a beehive shaped cover surmounted by a bird. A horned dragon is curled completely around the neck. Above on loop is a disk motif possibly representing a pearl. Below the dragon is a tortoise, and next to it a snake. Twelve standing, long robed, figures, each holding a baton, encircle the base of the neck. A small kneeling figure is squeezed into the middle of the row. The fabric is a buff clay covered with a thin, slightly crackled glaze that appears nearly colorless, but has a clear blue green tint where it collects in the crevices. This type of pottery is called yingqing.
credit_line: Gift of Charles L. Reese, 1979

title: Hanging
creator: Tongying Wu
description: Indigo cloth with batik design of Great Wall of China and Han style horses pulling carriages.  Design in white, black, orange.  Made by Miao artist Tongying Wu.  Imitation of seal in rectangular shape at bottom right corner.
credit_line: Gift of Tongying Wu, 1997

title: Painting
description: Black watercolor on white paper. Two birds. There is handwriting on the painting which reads: "Kao Yi. Pillar. dot. 909. B. Ilus No 182." This refers to the que, or tower, located at the tomb of Gao Yi in Sichuan province. There is a depiction of two birds at the top which inspired this painting. It may  have been done by Anneliese Gutkind-Bulling based on illustrations in her book "The Meaning of China's Most Ancient Art".
credit_line: Gift of Anneliese Gutkind-Bulling, 1985

title: Rubbing
description: Fish from Tomb 5 from Shiziwan, Leshan. Fish are seen as auspicious signs in Han China. Commonly found throughout the Sichuan cliff tomb reliefs. Fish are connected with the idea of “plenty” because of linguistic similarities between the terminology for “fish” (yu 魚) and “plenty” (yu 餘). These connections persist into the popular beliefs of contemporary China where fish are eaten during Lunar New Year festivities. Black ink on rice paper. From Han tomb reliefs.
credit_line: Gift of Anneliese Gutkind-Bulling, 1985

title: Rubbing
description: Fish from Tomb 5 from Shiziwan, Leshan. Fish are seen as auspicious signs in Han China. Commonly found throughout the Sichuan cliff tomb reliefs. Fish are connected with the idea of “plenty” because of linguistic similarities between the terminology for “fish” (yu 魚) and “plenty” (yu 餘). These connections persist into the popular beliefs of contemporary China where fish are eaten during Lunar New Year festivities. Black ink on rice paper. From Han tomb reliefs.
credit_line: Gift of Anneliese Gutkind-Bulling, 1985

title: Puzzle
description: Chinese rings puzzle (九连环 jiulianhuan). The object of the puzzle is to remove the nine rings from the handle loop. Part of a set of carved ivory games bought in Canton China in 1866 by Lieutenant-Commander Joshua Bishop U.S.N.
credit_line: Gift of Elizabeth W. Bonsall and Mary W. Bonsall, 1927

title: Mortuary Figurine
description: Grave figurine of a girl with scarf. Hair in two knobs.
credit_line: Purchased from C. T. Loo, 1916

title: Raincoat
description: Raincoat. Collected in Japan and made of palm fiber. Such coats were often worn by field workers and fishermen during the rainy season. Raincoats of a similar design can be found throughout Asia including southern China, Taiwan and the Philippines. The coat is  folded and then layered so that the fibers criss-cross. The layered pieces are then stitched together.
credit_line: Gift of Susan "Peedee" Shaw, 2007

title: Compass
description: Luopan (羅盤). A wooden compass, possibly for Feng Shui.
credit_line: Received from various sources, pre-1929

title: Pouch
creator: Huang Baozhen
description: Pouch with bat and auspicious symbols.  Silk embroidery.
credit_line: Gift of Elizabeth and Willie Liu in memory of JiLin Wu  吴吉臨, 2012

title: Tile Fragment
description: Fragment from diamond-shaped earthen-ware tile with elephant motif.
credit_line: Purchased from C. T. Loo, 1916

title: Tile Fragment
description: Fragment from diamond-shaped earthen-ware tile with drapery motif.
credit_line: Purchased from C. T. Loo, 1916

title: Tile Fragment
description: Fragment from diamond-shaped earthen-ware tile with elephant motif.
credit_line: Purchased from C. T. Loo, 1916

title: Tile Fragment
description: Fragment from diamond-shaped earthen-ware tile with elephant motif.
credit_line: Purchased from C. T. Loo, 1916

description: Fragment from diamond-shaped earthen-ware tile with elephant motif.
credit_line: Purchased from C. T. Loo, 1916
