credit_line: Purchased from Alexander Scott, 1914

title: Flask
description: Flask.  Copper.  Toad-shaped.  3 turquoise in back of toad;  1 turquoise and 1 coral in head still intact but other coral (?) missing.  Loops on shoulder and slits in base for carrying strap which is missing.
credit_line: Gift of Mrs. Robert R. Service, 1951

title: Hand Drum Case
description: Hand drum case for drum (Damaru).  Polished wood with skin drumheads painted green.  Short, circular, with short waist around which is a loop of the cloth and leather carrying band ornamented with 5 groups each of 4 cowries; long pendant of cloth with silk tassels, ornamented with silver disc, carnelian, silver (?) and glass beads.  Such drums were originally made of human skull and human skin.  The cowries indicate it is an old type.
credit_line: Gift of Mrs. Robert R. Service, 1951

title: Milk Pitcher
description: Milk pitcher.  Brass.  High foot contracting to compressed globular body;  high, wide neck;  wider mouth withopen pouring spout at one side and with the vertical rim extended upward into a 7 lobed band on the opposite side above a wide strap handle.  Simple relief decoration of lines and dots on upper body and neck.
credit_line: Gift of Mrs. Robert R. Service, 1951

title: Trumpet
description: Kang-Dung.  Trumpet.
credit_line: Gift of Mrs. Sarah (William D.) Frishmuth, 1900

title: Wine Jug
description: Wine jug for headman.  Bronze.  High ring base, compressed globular body, high neck contracting slightly to mouth which is extended on one side to form a large open spout;  wide strap handle, with raised edges, on opposite side from rim to lower body.  Shou symbols in medallions on body;  small medallions on neck;  conventionalized cloud collar on lid.  The lid, which follows the shape of the mouth except that it does not quite reach the end of the spoout, is chained to the top of the handle.
credit_line: Gift of Mrs. Robert R. Service, 1951

title: Printing Block
description: Wood printing block for printing charms for inside charm boxes.
credit_line: Gift of Mrs. Robert R. Service, 1951

title: Ear Ornament
description: Bamboo with incised design blackened and bound in part with yellow grass. Worn by women.
credit_line: Gift of the Academy of Natural Sciences of Philadelphia, 1997

title: Ear Ornament
description: Bamboo with incised design blackened and bound in part with yellow grass. Worn by women.
credit_line: Gift of the Academy of Natural Sciences of Philadelphia, 1997

title: Ear Ornament
description: Bamboo with incised design blackened and bound in part with yellow grass. Worn by women.
credit_line: Gift of the Academy of Natural Sciences of Philadelphia, 1997

title: Ear Ornament
description: Bamboo with incised design blackened and bound in part with yellow grass. Worn by women.
credit_line: Gift of the Academy of Natural Sciences of Philadelphia, 1997

title: Mask
description: Mask.  Devil dancer's mask.  Chaplet of serpent and five skulls, rosette on each temple, yellow.  Full, fat green face, five white heads on headdress.
credit_line: Gift of G. B. Phillips, 1922

title: Gong
description: Metal, circular, convex.
credit_line: Gift of the Philadelphia Museum of Art, 1951

title: Base
description: Wooden carved base with legs for large malachite pottery plant jar.
credit_line: Purchased from Duveen Brothers, 1915

title: Lifter
description: Ivory moustache lifter.
credit_line: Gift of the Academy of Natural Sciences of Philadelphia, 1997

title: Figurine
description: Animal figurine.  Tiny clay figure on all fours.  Pottery?  No glaze.
credit_line: The Chinese Expedition, Carl W. Bishop, 1916

title: Cricket Cage
description: Gourd; cracked.
credit_line: Gift of the Philadelphia Museum of Art, 1951

title: Ring
description: Gray-green jade ring. Center hole drilled on a slant.
credit_line: Gift of James K. Gamble Jr., 1970

title: Ring
description: Brown jade or stone ring-incesed geometrical decoration on both sides.
credit_line: Gift of James K. Gamble Jr., 1970

title: Knife
description: Knife with ivory handle, steel blade.
credit_line: Gift of the Academy of Natural Sciences of Philadelphia, 1997

title: Base
description: Wooden carved base with legs for colossal imperial fishbowl decorated with dragons on a white background.
credit_line: Purchased from Duveen Brothers, 1915

title: Knife
description: Steel blade with wooden handle, covered with green enamel.
credit_line: Gift of the Academy of Natural Sciences of Philadelphia, 1997

title: Stand
description: A rabbit (a) made of rock crystal with a wooden (b) stand.
credit_line: Gift of Mr. and Mrs. Paul K. Addams, 1981

title: Medicine
description: Chung ii shik ( 鐘乳石) [a bell, milk [milky] stone. Stalactite.
credit_line: Gift of the Academy of Natural Sciences of Philadelphia, 1997

title: Vase Stand
description: Teakwood stand for vase (C680A).
credit_line: Purchased from Wanamaker's Department Store; subscription of Eldridge R. Johnson, 1927

title: Box
description: Multi-tiered lacquer box with trays which fit together into one unit with handle.
credit_line: Gift of the Estate of Helen Bonnell Scott, 1974

title: Arrow
description: One of three arrows.  Inscription of Chinese characters.  Shaft deeply notched, feathered more than one-third length, wrapped with bark at head.
credit_line: Gift of William H. Miller, 1916

title: Arrow
description: One of three arrows.  Inscription of Chinese characters.  Shaft deeply notched, feathered more than one-third length, wrapped with bark at head.
credit_line: Gift of William H. Miller, 1916

title: Arrow
description: One of three arrows.  Inscription of Chinese characters.  Shaft deeply notched, feathered more than one-third length, wrapped with bark at head.
credit_line: Gift of William H. Miller, 1916

title: Sheath
description: Sheath.  Wood covered with metal with relief decoration.
credit_line: Academy of Natural Science / University Museum Expedition to Southwest China and Tibet; Gordon T. Bowles, 1932

title: Ceremonial Pike
creator: Unknown
description: Pike with curved blade with small curved spike on concave side. Placed in front of a yamen ( 衙門) or official residences.
credit_line: Gift of Edward Bedloe, 1897

title: Pot
description: White marble in shape of lotus flower. Petals in relief decorate exterior.
credit_line: Gift of the Estate of Fred Maloof (Richard G. and Jennifer L. Maloof), 1994

title: Statue
description: Bronze group in one piece with seated Shennong 神農 (Japanese: Shinno) and standing Telesphorus.  Shennong has natural tufts of hair, eyebrows and beard.
credit_line: Bequest of Maxwell Sommerville, 1904

title: Amulet (uncertain)
description: One of four nearly identical pendants or amulets.  Rectangular hole at top.  Two metal rings.  Iniscription says chin-hsien, 9 hermits.
credit_line: Received from various sources, pre-1992

title: Hair Comb
description: Fine comb.  Wood.  Silver color inscription of 13 characters and a dragon.  Similar to 7544. 7541 through 7543 are a set.
credit_line: Gift of Francis C. Macauley, Esq.,1890

title: Fiddle Bow
description: Bamboo bow, light hair attached through notch at one end and through hole 6 cm from the other end.
credit_line: Gift of the Philadelphia Museum of Art, 1951

title: Bowl
description: Dark green jade with striations and mottled white. Oval footed bowl with thinly carved fluted body with pierced handles and lily blossoms with carved interiors. Wooden stand.
credit_line: Bequest of Robert C. Alexander, 1988

title: Belt Hook
description: Miniature bronze belt hook in form of bird with returned head.  Green patination.  Kept in blue fitted case with 81-7-2.
credit_line: Purchased from Sotheby Parke Bernet, 1981

title: Box Lid
description: Lidded box.  Small round box of elephant or mammouth ivory; Ming dragon pattern of the 15th-16th century.
credit_line: Gift of Mrs. George F. Becker, 1954

title: Box
description: Lidded box.  Small round box of elephant or mammouth ivory; Ming dragon pattern of the 15th-16th century.
credit_line: Gift of Mrs. George F. Becker, 1954

title: Base
description: Wooden carved base with legs for large myrtle green plant jar. The edges of the lip of the base are thicker than the bases for similar plant jars in the collection.
credit_line: Purchased from Duveen Brothers, 1915

title: Statue
description: Small seated Buddha holding object in each hand. Small prong on bottom of base. Location: Tier 3, right outside top.
credit_line: Gift of the Estate of Fred Maloof (Richard G. and Jennifer L. Maloof), 1994

title: Vase
description: Garlic head hu pot.  Thin bronze vase with brown patination and encrusted areas.  Circular base plate with rope pattern in center and three incised fine line circles.
credit_line: Purchased from T. M. Huang, 1913

title: Snuff Bottle
description: A peking glass, red overlay on clear glass bottle with a carnelian top. The motif is lotus plants and iris leaves, cut for presentation. Good.
credit_line: Gift of Mr. and Mrs. Paul K. Addams, 1981

title: Drum
description: Pang-ku, drum.  Used in theater or altars. Brown wooden frame with one skin head attached by two rows of small nails. Good condition.
credit_line: Gift of Mrs. Sarah (William D.) Frishmuth, 1900

title: Statue
description: Small seated Buddha with small prong in base. Holds a small object in hand. Location: 3rd tier, outside top niche.
credit_line: Gift of the Estate of Fred Maloof (Richard G. and Jennifer L. Maloof), 1994

title: Headdress Pin
description: Manchu woman's headdress pin of green-dyed walrus ivory. Dye of copper oxide was originally applied to walrus ivory to imitate jade or malachite, later highly prized for itself.
credit_line: Gift of Stephen D. Pyle, 1954

title: Window
description: Single keystone-shaped peice of glass framed in wood. Corners reinforeced with "L" shaped brass(?) peices. Small lip on front bottom of window
credit_line: Gift of the Estate of Fred Maloof (Richard G. and Jennifer L. Maloof), 1994

title: Vase
description: Cloisonne Vase.  Ring base, nearly straight sides, high neck, flaring rim.  Greenish blue ground with red, yellow, dark blue, green and gold floral decoration.
credit_line: Gift of Van Antwerp Lea in the name of Arthur H. Lea, 1938

title: Vase
description: Ts'ien t'ung. Vase (one of a pair) to hold bamboo tallies.  Placed on the altar of the shrine of the Judgement God. 15402 and 15403 are a pair.
credit_line: Gift of Dr. W. W. McClure, 1892

title: Vase
description: Ts'ien t'ung. Vase (one of a pair) to hold bamboo tallies.  Placed on the altar of the shrine of the Judgement God. 15402 and 15403 are a pair.
credit_line: Gift of Dr. W. W. McClure, 1892

title: Spearhead
description: Bronze, hollow, faceted, octagonal spearhead (mao 矛) with a shaft. The piece is cast with a flat triangular double edged blade. Smooth olive green surface with patches of bright green encrustation.
credit_line: Purchased from Sotheby Parke Bernet, 1979

title: Drum
description: Pang-ku, drum.  Used in theater. Wood barrel, one skin head with hair remaining. Single row of nails. The skin is stretched and holes made in edge. Wood cracked.
credit_line: Gift of Mrs. Sarah (William D.) Frishmuth, 1900

title: Statue
description: Small seated figure on rectangular base with small prong on bottom. Figure wears necklace, crown, flowing sash and hold a rat. Location: Tier 3, outside shelf, left, bottom.
credit_line: Gift of the Estate of Fred Maloof (Richard G. and Jennifer L. Maloof), 1994

title: Slit Drum
description: Pan-rectangular block of wood, a slit running the length of either side (opposite sides-corners) to be fastened to the side of Kou. Top and bottom slightly convex. Good condition.
credit_line: Gift of the Philadelphia Museum of Art, 1951

title: Drum
description: Pang-ku, drum.  Convex drum chiefly used in popular orchestra. Brown wood frame, one skin head attached by three rows of large nails. Metal band around bottom. Crack in frame.
credit_line: Gift of Mrs. Sarah (William D.) Frishmuth, 1900

title: Figurine
description: Caparisoned unglazed pottery horse on unglazed rectangular plint with one hoof raised. Braided mane and arched neck leaning backwards. Terracotta colored hooves, tail and decorative trappings. Buff pottery with traces of pigment. Wooden stand. Custom glass case.
credit_line: Bequest of Robert C. Alexander, 1988

title: Lantern
description: Small 6-sided lantern. Painted wire mesh on sides with filligree designs. 12 small metal tassels hang from top and bottom. Small hanging chain. Location 3rd tier stage, right side
credit_line: Gift of the Estate of Fred Maloof (Richard G. and Jennifer L. Maloof), 1994

title: Violin
description: Ho-ho. Perforated bamboo body. Drum-shaped wooden front. Two double grooves around center of body and one double groove each around front and back ends of body. Bamboo bow with light hair. Only bow and body present.
credit_line: Gift of Mrs. Sarah (William D.) Frishmuth, 1900

title: Beam
description: "L" shaped beam stained black with 4 small rectangular holes on top side, 4 square pegs on bottom. Outside edge carved with floral design. Rests on large base side and front, supports side and front screens.
credit_line: Gift of the Estate of Fred Maloof (Richard G. and Jennifer L. Maloof), 1994

title: Beam
description: "L" shaped beam stained black with 4 small rectangular holes on top side, 4 square pegs on bottom. Outside edge carved with floral design. Rests on large base side and front, supports side and front screens.
credit_line: Gift of the Estate of Fred Maloof (Richard G. and Jennifer L. Maloof), 1994

title: Gong
description: Brass gong with flat raised surface. 3 holes in rim for attachment to handle. Handle of horn with circular brass ring with 3 triangular extensions, perpendicular to ring with string to tie to holes in gong. Good condition. Gong detached from handle.
credit_line: Gift of the Philadelphia Museum of Art, 1951

title: Shrine
description: Base of shrine stained black, 4 legs, 4 small holes on top. Bottom lip carved with slight undulating pattern, bottom of legs curved up, in. 3 small slits on back side, 3rd leg in back.
credit_line: Gift of the Estate of Fred Maloof (Richard G. and Jennifer L. Maloof), 1994

title: Beam
description: Wooden beam stained black, one edge rounded, one edge slanted with floral design. 2 rectangular holes on bottom edge 7.0 cm long. Through 1.0 cm wide running length of bottom side. Lies on ground in front of shrine.
credit_line: Gift of the Estate of Fred Maloof (Richard G. and Jennifer L. Maloof), 1994

title: Statue
description: Man standing in S-curve position on round base, painted red & gold. Wears long, flowing gold garment. Holds small red ball in both hands. Gold hair, black hair in 2 buns. Paint fading in sections, small chip on one of the buns.
credit_line: Gift of the Estate of Fred Maloof (Richard G. and Jennifer L. Maloof), 1994

title: Snuff Bottle
description: A rectangular amber bottle with carvings of pine trees two cranes (one on side edge), a deer, and a sacred fungus. It has a jadeite bead as a replaced top. Originally the top was the upper part of the gourd in coral. The jar top is inappropriate. The bottle is good.
credit_line: Gift of Mr. and Mrs. Paul K. Addams, 1981

title: Pillow
description: Pillow for Buddha image to rest upon.  Rectangular shaped pillow with tassel at each corner.  Cloth on top and bottom are gold and grey woven material with flowers and reverse swastika designs.  Edges are finished with metallic thread which are bound on to pillow.  Ends of thread become the tassels at the corners.
credit_line: Gift of the Estate of Fred Maloof (Richard G. and Jennifer L. Maloof), 1994

title: Drum
description: Po-fou, used for Confucian services. Drum with two drum sticks (A848B-C). Wood painted red, two skin heads with hair remaining. Some lettering on the heads. Attached with two rows of nails. Also alternating design of six, nine, made with nails around the rim. Heads rent, wood cracked. Two bamboo sticks.
credit_line: Gift of Mrs. Sarah (William D.) Frishmuth, 1900

title: Musical Scraper
description: Yu (敔). Musical instrument played by scraping the back. Used in Confucian ceremonies. In the form of a qilin.
credit_line: Gift of Mrs. Sarah (William D.) Frishmuth, 1900

title: Pot
description: Four pieces of wood with burnt ends are coming out of the top, top is painted grey with two legs.  The jade is shaped like a circle with three protrusions.  One part of the jade is especially dark.
credit_line: Gift of the Estate of Fred Maloof (Richard G. and Jennifer L. Maloof), 1994

title: Saucer Fragment
provenience: United States of America | Alaska | Nessudat | Yakutat Bay | Lost River
description: "English" soft-paste china. "Blue flow" floral design; formerly a saucer.
credit_line: University Museum / Bryn Mawr College Expedition to Alaska; Frederica de Laguna, 1953

title: Folding Fan
credit_line: Received from various sources, pre-1992

title: Flask
description: Flask. Copper. Toad-shaped. Three jewels on back and three at head missing. Gyarong garter carrying strap through two horizontal loops on shoulder and through two slits in sides of base.
credit_line: Gift of Mrs. Robert R. Service, 1951

title: Book Cover
description: Book cover.  Dark wood splendidly carved. Three seated Buddhas in niches. Traces of gilding.
credit_line: Alexander Scott Expedition to India, 1915-1918

title: Milk Pitcher
description: Milk pitcher.  Brass.  High foot contracting to compressed globular body;  high, wide neck;  wider mouth withopen pouring spout at one side and with the vertical rim extended upward into a 7 lobed band on the opposite side above a wide strap handle.  Simple relief decoration of lines and dots on upper body and neck.
credit_line: Gift of Mrs. Robert R. Service, 1951

title: Offering Vase
description: Offering vase from altar.  Bronze.  High annular base, globular body sloping to cylindrical neck with wide concave rim.  Simple lotus collar; triskelion in medallion.
credit_line: Gift of Mrs. Robert R. Service, 1951

title: Necklace
description: Silver amulet container (chhedi ka jantar) on a necklace. The container is attached to a long cord of black threads bound in places with gold thread with a loop and button made of thread. The central medallion is a large square with small diamond shapes around the edges with larger ones at each corner. The corners have small circularl holes for tiny blue beads (two are missing). There are floral patterns underneath the glass in metal made up of eight small flowers surrounding one central flower. They are in concave forms in gold with pearl-like centers.
credit_line: Purchased from Alexander Scott, 1914

title: Statuette
description: Bronze Buddha.  Seated.  Tiny.  With spiral headdress, holding a big spoon.
credit_line: Bequest of Maxwell Sommerville, 1904

title: Ink Well
description: Inkwell from traveling writing.  Brass ink well in leather case attached by thong.  Pen case(51-4-59A) and pen(51-4-59B).
credit_line: Gift of Mrs. Robert R. Service, 1951

title: Bracelet
description: Open ends of bracelet terminate in snake heads.  "Worn to avert illness".
credit_line: Gift of Mrs. Robert R. Service, 1951

title: Statuette
description: Bronze statue. Chinese origin. Guanyin holding child.
credit_line: Purchased from Alexander Scott, 1914

title: Offering Vase
description: Brass offering vase.  From altar.  High annular base, globular body sloping to cylindrical neck with wide concave rim.  Lotus collar and lotus base, conventionalized pearl strings in center.
credit_line: Gift of Mrs. Robert R. Service, 1951

title: Jug
description: Jug.  Very crude cast bronze.  Ring base, globular body, neck contracting slightly to mouth;  high on one side is a spout probably intended to be conventionalization of monster mask.  Wide strap handle with raised edges.  Simple line and dot decortaion on neck and body including Shou symbols in medallions.
credit_line: Gift of Mrs. Robert R. Service, 1951

title: Knife Sheath
description: Wooden sheath covered with brass.  Conventional decoration in high relief.  Leather carrying straps.
credit_line: Gift of Mrs. Morgan Wing on behalf of the Estate of Florence C. Whitney, 1942

title: Teapot Lid
description: Lid for cast copper teapot.  Low foot, globular body, very short neck; high monster spout on one side of body; heavy, vertical loop handle with dragon opposite.  Lid stepped with knob on top.  The pot is #36-B, but the lid marked 36-B fits our 51-4-101 and has been catalogued with it; the lid catalogued as 51-4-98b is original number 20.
credit_line: Gift of Mrs. Robert R. Service, 1951

title: Relief
description: Ivory bas relief with carving of Demon King.
credit_line: Purchased from Alexander Scott, 1914

title: Holy Water Vase
description: Holy water vase.  Copper with brass cover and spout.  High lotus foot; globular body with flat shoulder; contracting neck; wide, overhanging cover with small mouth in center.  High spout from upper body.  Relief decoration; around cover, wheel and thunderbolt, 6 precious jewels, indeterminate, flaming sword; top of cover, lotus petals; monster at base of spout.
credit_line: Gift of Mrs. Robert R. Service, 1951

title: Teapot
description: Copper teapot trimmed with silver.
credit_line: Purchased from Alexander Scott, 1914

title: Meal Tray
description: Meal tray or stand.  Lacquered wood.  Square.  Red inside.
credit_line: Gift of Francis C. Macauley, 1891

title: Fan
description: Bamboo ribs; poor condition; poor bamboo paper, stained (dyed) brown.
credit_line: Gift of John Wanamaker, 1900

title: Fan
description: Bamboo ribs; poor condition; poor bamboo paper, stained (dyed) brown.
credit_line: Gift of John Wanamaker, 1900

title: Fan
description: White goose (?) feathers with blue enamelled metal butterfly decoration. Hollow ivory (?) handle.
credit_line: Received from various sources, pre-1985

title: Pendant
description: Gray white jade arc shaped pendant (璜 huang). Flat. Hole piercing each end.
credit_line: Gift of James K. Gamble Jr., 1970

title: Brush Holder
description: Pih kia. Pencil rack. Used upon altar of Judgement God.
credit_line: Gift of Dr. W. W. McClure, 1892

title: Back Scratcher
description: Back scratcher.  Bone with wooden handle.  Numbered 7164 by mistake.  Two fingers broken.
credit_line: Gift of Francis C. Macauley, Esq.,1890

title: Statue Fragment
description: Finger broken off from statue.  Probably from right hand.
credit_line: Purchased from C. T. Loo, 1924

title: Carving
description: Peach pit carved in form of man in chariot pulled by two horses with riders.
credit_line: Gift of James K. Gamble Jr., 1970

title: Ink
description: Chinese imperial ink.  In box.  Fine piece.  Dragon and cloud encircling.  Inscription 'Sun Lung inspect-made.'  Fragmentary.
credit_line: Gift of Benjamin Smith Lyman, 1891

title: Drum
description: Pang-ku, drum.  Used in theater. Wood, two skin heads attached by nails.
credit_line: Gift of Mrs. Sarah (William D.) Frishmuth, 1900

title: Statue
description: Figure sits cross-legged on base. Holds sword. Wears crown and flowered earrings.
credit_line: Gift of the Estate of Fred Maloof (Richard G. and Jennifer L. Maloof), 1994

title: Knife Sheath
description: Patterned hard edged blade of good quality.  Strap with character for good luck.
credit_line: Gift of Mrs. Morgan Wing on behalf of the Estate of Florence C. Whitney, 1942

title: Stand
description: Chuk tan. Pewter stand for candle (one of a pair). Oblong.  Company name Huang Yuan Zao.  Same shape as 15405, but a little larger.
credit_line: Gift of Dr. W. W. McClure, 1892

title: Painting
description: Painting on wooden panel. Subject: 5 different colored Buddhas. Center figure white with red garment. Flowers decorate dark blue background.
credit_line: Gift of the Estate of Fred Maloof (Richard G. and Jennifer L. Maloof), 1994

title: Bow
description: Lacquered wood with reed and cloth binding; snakeskin over ends; two inlaid diamonds of lighter wood near each end. Extremely sprung-when strung it is cupid's bow shape.
credit_line: Gift of William G. Hoffman, 1954

title: Fiddle
description: Erh-H'sien, small wood round head, neck slightly curved, 2 strings, 2 pegs. Lettering on back. Good condition: strings broken, 1 peg cracked.
credit_line: Gift of the Philadelphia Museum of Art, 1951

title: Gong
description: Gong handle of horn with circular brass ring with 3 triantural extensions, perpendicular to ring with string to tie to holes in gong.  Gong detached from handle 1972.
credit_line: Gift of the Philadelphia Museum of Art, 1951

title: Screen
description: Carved wooden screen stained black. 2 main panels each with different realistic flower/plant design. Panels surrounded by "cloud and ribbon" carvings. Side door.
credit_line: Gift of the Estate of Fred Maloof (Richard G. and Jennifer L. Maloof), 1994

title: Castanet
description: Cha-pan, used principally by beggars. Red cedar, dark, center castanet slightly thicken than other two. Outer part of one cracked, only part of string holding castanets together.
credit_line: Gift of the Philadelphia Museum of Art, 1951

title: Screen
description: Carved wooden screen stained black, 2 main panels each with different realistic flower/plant design. Panels surrounded by "cloud and ribbon" carvings. Side door.
credit_line: Gift of the Estate of Fred Maloof (Richard G. and Jennifer L. Maloof), 1994

title: Statue
description: Figure saeted on square base in lotus position. One hand is raised; other rests in lap. Wears heavy-looking robe. Base decorated with animal motifs.
credit_line: Gift of the Estate of Fred Maloof (Richard G. and Jennifer L. Maloof), 1994

title: Drum
description: Wood, circular shell with heads of skin nailed to it, brown.  Small, solid (almost) and heavy for its size.  Fair condition, some nails missing and wood cracked.  Heads intact
credit_line: Gift of the Philadelphia Museum of Art, 1951

title: Statue
description: Buddha standing in s-curve position on round red and gold base. Wears gold coat and shirt and red pants. Belly exposed. Hands: palms together. Gold face; hair in bun. Paint is peeling.
credit_line: Gift of the Estate of Fred Maloof (Richard G. and Jennifer L. Maloof), 1994

title: Belt Hook
description: Bronze belt hook in shape of horse.  Cast in rounded relief in the form of a horse in profile with short up-turned tail.  Long narrow hook extending from chest of horse.  Button on back side.  Green patina.
credit_line: Gift of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Bull, 1984

title: Fiddle
description: Ur-heen.  Round tabular body of light wood.  Neck of dark wood. Concave back of body with carved design.  Flat front is glued on.  Neck curved back at top slightly.  2 strings and 2 large bulbuous pegs.
credit_line: Gift of the Philadelphia Museum of Art, 1951

title: Moon Guitar
description: Yueqin, light wood, round body with 8 prs. of frets. Short neck with 2 frets. 4 strings. Poor condition. Crack in body, 6 frets missing, no pegs, no strings, top of peg box missing, body detached from neck.
credit_line: Gift of the Philadelphia Museum of Art, 1951

title: Rubbing
description: Ink-squeeze rubbing taken from a stone stele engraved with a portrait of Yan Hui 顏回, one of the disciples of Confucius. The subject of the portrait is identified by a title in xiaozhuan (“small seal script”) calligraphy. A eulogy in four rhyming lines follows.
credit_line: Museum Purchase, 1929

title: Statue
description: Small male deity with 4 arms. Two playing sitar-like instrument; 2nd pair holding rattles (?). Wears crown & flowing sash, standing on oval base. Location: Tier 3, right outside shelf, bottom.
credit_line: Gift of the Estate of Fred Maloof (Richard G. and Jennifer L. Maloof), 1994

title: Manuscript
description: Miniature sized manuscript.  Accordion style pages folded between two covers with fabric on exterior and gold paper covering the edges and on the interior of the book covers.  The paper is printed on one side in black with chinese characters.
credit_line: Gift of the Estate of Fred Maloof (Richard G. and Jennifer L. Maloof), 1994

title: Model
description: Small gate for shrine. Top: Green design. Bottom: wood inlaid mother-of-pearl on front side. Thin dark strips attached to top & bottom. Notches to attach gate to shrine. Location: Tier 3, notches into frame
credit_line: Gift of the Estate of Fred Maloof (Richard G. and Jennifer L. Maloof), 1994

title: Snuff Bottle
description: A flattened shaped carnelian bottle. The motif is of Li Tieguai with his magic gourd. The reverse side is a tree peony with a bird on a branch and a cicada on the rock below it. The top has a little boy.
credit_line: Gift of Mr. and Mrs. Paul K. Addams, 1981

title: Flute
description: Transverse Flute (Titzu per Agi Jambor). Bamboo, dark brown, 5 sections, ivory tipped, 10 holes in front: 3 on middle section; 5 on second section, 2 on back: 2 on first section. Green and white etched flowers and bird on 4th section. One small crack. No Seder # (?).
credit_line: Gift of Mr. Sigmund Beel, 1896

title: Table Setting Case
description: Pair of ivory chopsticks (A-B)  in an elaborate case (C) of carved wood with heavy silver fittings. The silver is decorated in repousse with dragons, and with incised floral patterns and auspicious characters. Case contains one large empty space, possibly for a knife or pipe.
credit_line: Received from various sources, pre-1992

title: Model
description: Small "couch". Front: green grillwork set into frame. Sides: gold cloth panels with 10 strands of beads hanging from each. Top panel: red cloth with floral pattern held down along back edge by piece of ivory. Location: 3rd tier, left of Buddha angled near back.
credit_line: Gift of the Estate of Fred Maloof (Richard G. and Jennifer L. Maloof), 1994

title: Moon Guitar
description: Fiddle.  Moon shaped. Light wood on front and back of body. Sides and neck are dark wood. Four strings and ten frets. Four roundish hexagonal pegs. Red paper with Chinese characters in center of front of body. Poor condition with body badly cracked. One peg is missing as are string holder and all strings.
credit_line: Gift of Mr. Sigmund Beel, 1896

title: Lute Fragment
creator: Unknown
description: Sanxian. Favorite of street ballad singers. Three strings, small circular body of dark wood, with snakeskin covering both front and back. Long neck of dark wood curving back into scroll above pegs. Three pegs, tapering and hexagonal in shape. Poor condition. Strings missing, wood broken near bottom peg and skins broken on both sides.
credit_line: Gift of Mrs. Sarah (William D.) Frishmuth, 1900

title: Drum Tripod
creator: Unknown
description: Bamboo tripod for drum.  Bamboo, 3 long sticks fastened together with wire through holes app. 1/4 of the distance from top.  Top of each pole plugged with wood, metal ring around top and bottom of each pole.  Darker wooden pointed tips to bottom of each pole inserted and nailed in L. of each pole app. 79 cm.
credit_line: Deposited by R. Stewart Culin, 1893

title: Pendant
description: Loop of metal at top of this piece suggests that this is a pendant.  Two ornate fish which appear to be hooked to top of pendant.  Fish are belly to belly, making the design symmetrical.  Pendant is hollow.
credit_line: Bequest of Maxwell Sommerville, 1904

title: Drum
description: Kio-ku, drum.  For temple orchestra.  Skin on one side only. Head is tan in middle with black circle around it 4 cm. wide. Within the black is a thin red circle. The side is made of painted black wood. A metal rim goes around the bottom. Three small metal rings for suspension. Condition is good.
credit_line: Gift of Mrs. Sarah (William D.) Frishmuth, 1900

title: Medicine
description: 砂仁. Brown seeds. Seeds of several species of Amomum, of which Amomum Grana Paradisi furnishes the best, imported from India and the Malayan Archipelago. A stomachic and stimulant; used also to flavor spirituous liquors and in cookery. From Singapore and Penang. Value at Ningbo, $48 per picul. One of a collection of samples of Chinese medicine, each in an individual glass jar sealed with cork top.
credit_line: Gift of R. Stewart Culin, pre-1903

title: Sword
description: Long single-edged steel blade with nearly parallel sides; cutting edge curved to point; groove near back on both faces; Tang inserted in wooden grip which is almost completely covered with fibre rope; circular iron guard with overhanging rim; wooden sheath covered with black leather; iron band at top and tip and two iron rings on upper half connected by ornamental bar.
credit_line: Gift of Mrs. Morgan Wing on behalf of the Estate of Florence C. Whitney, 1942

title: Flute
description: Laquered bamboo flute with ivory ends.  There are three small cracks in the wood.  Twelve holes in total: one for mouth, next one for a thin membrane to be places over to create a buzzing sound (remnants of the membrane still remaining on this flute), next six for fingers, next two (on bottom) for decorative yellow tassel, and next two for pitch adjustment. Faint inscription above mouth hole. Played transversely, on either the right or left side of the player. Used in kunqu opera accompaniment, traditional chinese orchestra, smaller silk and bamboo ensembles, and as a solo instrument. The inscription is the poetic couplet "洛陽三月花如錦，多少功夫織得成." It is from the poem "Orioles Flying To and Fro" (鶯梭) by Liu Kezhuang 劉克莊. There are two indecipherable marks following the couplet. The couplet translates to "In Luoyang the third month's flowers are like a brocade; how much time did it take to weave them to completion?"
credit_line: Gift of Mrs. Sarah (William D.) Frishmuth, 1900

title: Figurine
description: Figurine horse.  Pottery, unglazed.
credit_line: Purchased from Yamanaka & Company, 1915

title: Sword
creator: Unknown
description: Short sword with sheath (A1395B).  Handle of wood with a brass tip.  Forged blade with forging flaws.  Disassociated pieces joined together.  Guigong, carved demon work on sheath sides.
credit_line: Purchased from Alexander Scott, 1914

title: Statue Contents
description: Contents of gilded statuette 20946.  Silk cloths and threads, powdered sandal wood in a glass jar.
credit_line: Gift of William Pepper, 1898

title: Water Pipe Bowl
description: Bowl of water pipe.  Probably made in India for bowl of water pipe but used by Tibetans as holy water vase.  Brass.  Globular; fluted; lotiform collar.
credit_line: Gift of Mrs. Robert R. Service, 1951

title: Earring
description: Silver earring.  One of a pair.  Heart-shaped with inset turquoise; 4 silver chains each with 2 coral beads and each terminating in flat pendant.  Heavy hook at top.
credit_line: Gift of Mrs. Robert R. Service, 1951

title: Cartoon
culture: Tibetan | Tibetan Buddhism | Lamaism | Gelupgpa Sect
description: Cartoons or pounces for Lama Paintings to direct the artist.  Paper.  Green Tara.
credit_line: Gift of Lawrence Sickman, 1953

title: Cartoon
culture: Tibetan | Tibetan Buddhism | Lamaism | Gelupgpa Sect
description: Cartoons or pounces for Lama Paintings to direct the artist.  Paper.  Mahakala.
credit_line: Gift of Lawrence Sickman, 1953

title: Knife
description: Handle is two-tiered, darkened wood, slightly curved.  Has criss-cross enclosed carved pattern under the tier line.
credit_line: Bequest of Chester A. Asher, Jr., 1973

title: Teapot
description: Cast copper teapot.  Low foot, globular body, very short neck; high monster spout on one side of body; heavy, vertical loop handle with dragon opposite.  Lid stepped with knob on top.  The pot is #36-B, but the lid marked 36-B fits our 51-4-101 and has been catalogued with it; the lid catalogued as 51-4-98b is original number 20.
credit_line: Gift of Mrs. Robert R. Service, 1951

title: Snuff Box
description: Snuff box. Silver. Cylindrical with cover attached by chain.  Three carved faces on top; animal face on lower half.
credit_line: Purchased from Alexander Scott, 1914

title: Scabbard
creator: Unknown
description: Sheath for short sword.  Leather with brass trimmings.  Disassociated pieces joined together.  Guigong, carved demon work on sheath sides.
credit_line: Purchased from Alexander Scott, 1914

title: Tsamba Box Lid
description: Lid for one of a nested set of Tsamba boxes.  For holding barley flour(Tsamba), salt and condiments.  Wood with floral patterns in black on lustrous copper varnish. Small lid which fits into the mouth of 51-4-76 C.  Rounded top with a knob now missing.
credit_line: Gift of Mrs. Robert R. Service, 1951

title: Powder Horn
description: Section of yak horn; metalwork with dragons probably from Chinese armor; jewel studding of turquoise and false coral; woven tape sling.  Measuring device on top.  Small powder horn used for priming, made of end of yak horn, has ingenius spring device for opening.  Bullet pouch with crude hand-cast lead pellets.
credit_line: Gift of Mrs. Robert R. Service, 1951

title: Earring
description: Silver earring.  One of a pair.  Heart-shaped with inset turquoise; 4 silver chains each with 2 coral beads and each terminating in flat pendant.  Heavy hook at top.
credit_line: Gift of Mrs. Robert R. Service, 1951

title: Sword
description: Sword.  Steel and iron blade, straight and single-edged.  Rather simple flat hilt covered with yak hide;  inverted rectangular up guard and flat 5-sided end, both of silver; coral jewel.
credit_line: Gift of Mrs. Robert R. Service, 1951

title: Sheath
description: Sheath.  Wood with iron binding in one piece; binding retains ornamental pierced brass panel.
credit_line: Gift of Mrs. Robert R. Service, 1951

title: Knife
description: Middle-sized knife with darkened, round handle with flat top.
credit_line: Bequest of Chester A. Asher, Jr., 1973

title: Short Sword
description: Short sword.  Handle bound with cord and brass tip.  Made out of several disassociated pieces.  Blade is not Tibetan form but Afghan form.  Pommel cap and sheath are of different quality and design.  Crude example of Tibetan Guigong or Demon work.
credit_line: Purchased from Alexander Scott, 1914

title: Bracelet
description: Silver bracelet.  Heavy.  Oval with open ends.  Twin lion heads decorated with enamel.  Pattern goes back more than two thousand years among the Scythians.  Probably Chinese workmanship.
credit_line: Gift of Mrs. Robert R. Service, 1951

title: Tsamba Box
description: One of a nested set of Tsamba boxes.  For holding barley flour(Tsamba), salt and condiments.  Wood with floral patterns in black on lustrous copper varnish.  This box-like vessel fits into the neck of 51-4-76A.  Has disc base with wide flange below convex sides and narrow shoulder, and short vertical rim.  51-4-76C fits into the mouth of 51-4-76B.
credit_line: Gift of Mrs. Robert R. Service, 1951

title: Tsamba Box
description: One of a nested set of Tsamba boxes.  For holding barley flour(Tsamba), salt and condiments.  Wood with floral patterns in black on lustrous copper varnish. Vessel which fits into the mouth of 51-4-76B.  Similar to B but has a small lid, 51-4-76D.
credit_line: Gift of Mrs. Robert R. Service, 1951

title: Knife
description: Smallest knife, undarkened rounded handle with slightly rounded top and two lines cut around top for decoration.
credit_line: Bequest of Chester A. Asher, Jr., 1973

title: Scabbard
description: Sheath for short sword.  Sheath of wood with brass trimmings.  Made out of several disassociated pieces.  Pommel cap and sheath are of different quality and design.  Crude example of Tibetan Guigong or Demon work.
credit_line: Purchased from Alexander Scott, 1914

title: Tsamba Box
description: Lid for one of a nested set of Tsamba boxes.  For holding barley flour(Tsamba), salt and condiments.  Wood with floral patterns in black on lustrous copper varnish. Small lid which fits into the mouth of 51-4-76 C.  Rounded top with a knob now missing.
credit_line: Gift of Mrs. Robert R. Service, 1951

title: Incense Burner
description: Bottom section of silver incense burner.  Light sheet metal, shaped and embossed.  Bottom section is pedestal with petal-shape to dish and small sunken circular area at center.  Lid is rounded and tiered with embossed flower on lower tier and openwork in the shape of three Chinese coins on upper tear.  Knob at top.
credit_line: Gift of Mrs. Winnifred S. Miller, 1997

title: Pen Case
description: Pen case from traveling writing set.  Brass with three dragons in pierced technique and reverse side with engraved scales.  Pen(51-4-59B) and Brass inkwell(51-4-59C).
credit_line: Gift of Mrs. Robert R. Service, 1951

title: Dagger
description: Dagger.  Straight single edged steel blade.  Cutting edge bent sharply to point.  Tang inserted in sheet silver grip with four lobed guard.  One section entirely bound with silver wire.  Red stone inlay.  Leather carrying strap.  With wood sheath (42-30-287B).  Combination of recycled elements joined together.  Hilt is characteristically Tibetan.  Hairpin pattern steel blade.  Guigong or carved demon work on sides of sheath.  Central pierced work in iron instead of silver.  Re-used central section has three levels of pierced work with clouds, dragon and foliage.  This section could be as old as 16th century or more recent, either re-used because of its beautiful metalwork or because it was an heirloom.
credit_line: Gift of Mrs. Morgan Wing on behalf of the Estate of Florence C. Whitney, 1942

title: Dagger
description: Dagger(A1103A) and Scabbard(A1103B).  Shark skin grip on the handle.  Tibetan hilt form.  Leather band on the scabbard.  Bhutanese type scabbard.  Sheath may have been made at a different time than blade.
credit_line: Purchased from W. O. Oldman, 1911

title: Trumpet
description: Telescope trumpet in three sections. Copper with brass trim. Large ornate bell. Buldging ring marks begininng of section. Bell: buldging ring marks beginning of section. Bell: three buldging rings of copper with two rows of brass leaves between each section defined by buldges; rim has ornately worked brass trim. Mouthpiece missing.
credit_line: Gift of Mrs. Charles B. Darrow, 1968

title: Cartoon
culture: Tibetan | Tibetan Buddhism | Lamaism | Gelupgpa Sect
description: Cartoons or pounces for Lama Paintings to direct the artist.  Paper.  Eleven headed Avalokitesvara.
credit_line: Gift of Lawrence Sickman, 1953

title: Knife
description: Hand hammered brass trimmings on water buffalo hide case.  Case is studded with native stones set in tree sap.  Opposite side is unornamented leather sewn together along center.
credit_line: Bequest of Chester A. Asher, Jr., 1973

title: Incense Burner Lid
description: Lid for silver incense burner.  Light sheet metal, shaped and embossed.  Bottom section is pedestal with petal-shape to dish and small sunken circular area at center.  Lid is rounded and tiered with embossed flower on lower tier and openwork in the shape of three Chinese coins on upper tear.  Knob at top.
credit_line: Gift of Mrs. Winnifred S. Miller, 1997

title: Long Sword
description: Long sword.  Chieftain's.  Steel and iron blade, straight and single-edged.  Hilt of brass with characteristic inverted cup guard; brass wire trimming;  insets of carved silver and false coral.  Unusual brass rather than silver grip, may have been gilded on the grip.  This one is Tibetan, prior to Chinese influence as it is still made to be worn tucked in the belt.  Good quality.  Silver insets are embossed.  It is missing a section of nice textile, back textile is usually plain.  Might have had a boss on the back side.  Blade has hairpin pattern which is visible.  Has all the typical features of Eastern Tibet.  The shape of the iron channel and silver are characteristic of Durge work.
credit_line: Gift of Mrs. Robert R. Service, 1951

title: Teapot
description: Teapot copper trimmed with brass and jewels(coral and turquoise).  Shape similar to 51-4-94, etc.  with unusual monster spout and dragon handle; heavy lotus base.  On each side of body is a gilded plaque with a folk-lore Mang dragon, said to be from Chinese armor.  Plain stepped lid with rounded lower section and with knob.
credit_line: Gift of Mrs. Robert R. Service, 1951

title: Rubbing
description: Rubbing from a stone carving dated to the Ming Dynasty depicting Guanyin.
credit_line: Museum Purchase, 1929

title: Statue
description: One of a pair of pottery lions.  Blue glazed.  Brown stands.
credit_line: Purchased from / at the World's Columbian Exposition, 1893

title: Statue
description: One of a pair of pottery lions.  Blue glazed.  Brown stands.
credit_line: Purchased from / at the World's Columbian Exposition, 1893

title: Tube
description: Brown jade or stone tube, possibly a cong. Cork bottom. No design.
credit_line: Gift of James K. Gamble Jr., 1970

title: Lute
description: Sanxian. Three stringed fiddle.  In long box.  Snake skin or lizard skin.
credit_line: Gift of Mr. Sigmund Beel, 1896

title: Lid
description: Small cloisonne container. Fish scales decoration in dark blue. Stylized character of longetivity on top (turquiose inside).
credit_line: Gift of James K. Gamble Jr., 1970

title: Container
description: Small cloisonne container. Fish scales decoration in dark blue. Stylized character of longetivity on top (turquiose inside).
credit_line: Gift of James K. Gamble Jr., 1970

title: Knife
description: Patterned hard edged blade of good quality.  Strap with character for good luck.
credit_line: Gift of Mrs. Morgan Wing on behalf of the Estate of Florence C. Whitney, 1942

title: Spectacles Case
description: Case for spectacles (7053A).  A dull red lacquer case.  Spray of iris engraved on one side.  Chinese inscription on the other.  Lined with red silk.
credit_line: Deposited by R. Stewart Culin, 1890

title: Snuff Case
description: Snuff case.  Ivory figurine of mouse or jewel-spitting mongoose.
credit_line: Academy of Natural Science / University Museum Expedition to Southwest China and Tibet; Gordon T. Bowles, 1932

title: Incense Burner
creator: Li Ho Yang Hsi
description: Hiang lu. Incense burner, for three incense sticks. Used upon altar of Judgement God.  Pewter.  Company name stamped on bottom: Li Ho Yang Xi (利和样锡).
credit_line: Gift of Dr. W. W. McClure, 1892

title: Painting
creator: Shen Tianchi
description: Painting on paper:  Shandong province.  Shentong Pass, Christian chapel looking northwards:  two banks of the Yellow River (Huang-he) and two mountains.  In the year 1910 winter CE;  painted by Shen Tianchi, 沈天池.
credit_line: Received from various sources, pre-1929

title: Snuff Bottle Lid
description: A bottle of snowflake glass with blue overlay (a) with a dragon motif. Two dragons with a flaming pearl between them, stylized waves below. The (b) top is porcelain.
credit_line: Gift of Mr. and Mrs. Paul K. Addams, 1981

title: Cricket Cage (uncertain)
description: Ornate basket; fine splints in twilled weave, probably bamboo.  Possibly a cricket cage.  Fine splints in twilled weave, probably bamboo.  Various designs.  Open work.  Bottom and cover separate.  Oval.  Small.
credit_line: Gift of Mrs. David English Dallam, 1937

title: Cricket Cage Cover (uncertain)
description: Ornate basket; fine splints in twilled weave, probably bamboo.  Possibly a cricket cage.  Fine splints in twilled weave, probably bamboo.  Various designs.  Open work.  Bottom and cover separate.  Oval.  Small.
credit_line: Gift of Mrs. David English Dallam, 1937

title: Drum
description: Pong-ku frame drum. Brown wooden frame, one skin head painted black. Two rows of nails, metal band around bottom. Metal rim is loose, wood is cracked and most of the paint is discolored and chipped.
credit_line: Gift of Mrs. Sarah (William D.) Frishmuth, 1900

title: Screen
description: Carved wooden screen stained black. 2 main panels with different realistic flower/plant design. Panels surrounded by "cloud and ribbon" carvings. Screen held in frame of lighter colored wood, metal hinge length of door. Front door.
credit_line: Gift of the Estate of Fred Maloof (Richard G. and Jennifer L. Maloof), 1994

title: Drum
description: Po-fou, drum.  One of two (A852A-B).  Barrel drums for Confucian ceremony.  Smaller of the two.  Wood, painted red with metal heads attached by one row of studs.  One large metal ring on side.  Head bent and paint chipping.
credit_line: Gift of Mrs. Sarah (William D.) Frishmuth, 1900

title: Moon Guitar
description: Circular body, front of light wood, neck and sides of dark wood. End of neck curves forward and is carved in the shape of a bat. Four long fluted pegs (tapered). Ten frets. Fair condition. Crack in body, and two strings are missing.
credit_line: Gift of the Philadelphia Museum of Art, 1951

title: Screen
description: Carved wooden screen stained black. 2 main panels with different realistic flower/plant designs. Panels surrounded by "cloud and ribbon" carvings. Screen held in frame of lighter colored wood. Metal hinge down length of one side. Front door.
credit_line: Gift of the Estate of Fred Maloof (Richard G. and Jennifer L. Maloof), 1994

title: Snuff Bottle
description: A white glass inside painted bottle (a) with overlay of red glass. One side has a hill and valley landscape with a poem, and the other side is a painting of a cricket eating a cabbage and a butterfly. The stopper (b) is made of agate.
credit_line: Gift of Mr. and Mrs. Paul K. Addams, 1981

title: Linchpin
description: Bronze axle cap and lynchpin.  Tapered axle cap decorated with two cowrie shell bands and a single raised band with scrolls.  Lynchpin is long and rectangular with crouching leopard terminal.  Incised spots and other details on leapard.  Other end of lynchpin with hole.  Green patina.
credit_line: Gift of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Bull, 1984

title: Axle Cap
description: Bronze axle cap and lynchpin.  Tapered axle cap decorated with two cowrie shell bands and a single raised band with scrolls.  Lynchpin is long and rectangular with crouching leopard terminal.  Incised spots and other details on leapard.  Other end of lynchpin with hole.  Green patina.
credit_line: Gift of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Bull, 1984

title: Axle Cap
description: Bronze axle cap and lynchpin.  Tapered axle cap decorated with two cowrie shell bands and a single raised band with scrolls.  Lynchpin is long and rectangular with crouching leopard terminal.  Incised spots and other details on leapard.  One end of lynchpin is broken off and missing.  Green patina.
credit_line: Gift of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Bull, 1984

title: Linchpin
description: Bronze axle cap and lynchpin.  Tapered axle cap decorated with two cowrie shell bands and a single raised band with scrolls.  Lynchpin is long and rectangular with crouching leopard terminal.  Incised spots and other details on leapard.  One end of lynchpin is broken off and missing.  Green patina.
credit_line: Gift of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Bull, 1984

title: Rubbing
description: Ink-squeeze rubbing taken from a stone stele engraved with a portrait of Guan Yu 關羽 (d. 220 CE), the military leader from the last decades of the Eastern Han Dynasty, later a deity widely worshipped in China. The subject of the portrait is identified by a title in “seal script” calligraphy, below which is a depiction of a seal and its impression reading “Seal of the Lord of Hanshou ting”, that being one of the titles of the historical Guan Yu. Along the left hand edge of the image, a vertical line of text provides a date, 1721, and the statement that it was “reverently copied by the devotee Li Jintai of Baishan.” Baishan probably refers to the Changbai mountain range, and by extension to Manchuria. The identity of Li Jintai is not known, nor is it clear whether the copying referred to is the copying of a painting, or the reproduction of the painting onto a stele.
credit_line: Museum Purchase, 1929

title: Moon Guitar
description: Moon shaped fiddle. Light wood on front and back of body. Sides and neck are dark wood. Four strings and ten frets. Four roundish hexagonal pegs. Red paper with Chinese characters in center of front of body. Poor condition with body badly cracked. One peg is missing as are string holder and all strings.
credit_line: Gift of Mr. Sigmund Beel, 1896

title: Violin
description: Erk-h'sien, hammer shape, 1 end covered with snakeskin, 2 strings, hollow cylindrical body with bamboo neck inserted towards front. 2 long tapering, fluted pegs one above the other. Thin curved wooden bow with hair braid one quarter of the way down. Good condition. Head slightly warped.
credit_line: Gift of the Philadelphia Museum of Art, 1951

title: Seal (Object)
description: One of two (67-12-1 and 67-12-2) soapstone seals.  Mutton fat color.  Square base tapering into a poised dragon statuette.  Double-tail carved in relief.  Minute detail etching of dragon's head and back noteworthy.  This one says Ho Chih Chih Yin, Seal of Ho Chih.  Four characters.
credit_line: Gift of James L. G. Parsons, 1967

title: Vase
description: A rock crystal (A) vase with (B) cover and ring handles with a fitted wooden (C) stand. There is a lion finial on the cover. The vase is surrounded by a reticulated manchurian crane and lotus. Qilin (mythical beast) breathing out vapor. On the obverse there is a phoenix. Lion heads with protruding tongues on the vases shoulders.
credit_line: Gift of Mr. and Mrs. Paul K. Addams, 1981

title: Figure
description: Unglazed figure of a horse with elaborate trappings; the horse stands foresquare on a square base with head slightly raised; elaborate trappings consist of plumes on the head, neck and rump with molded design of fleur de lys at the neck; elaborate saddle cloth sweeping backward; traces of pigment; extensive earth remaining on the figure; extensive restoration on the body, legs, base, saddle cloth, plumes and head.
credit_line: Gift of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas S. Gates, Jr., 1979

title: Statuette
description: Grey green and bright green jade, rind of boulder remains on left side and bottom.  Lady with deer.  One of a pair (C676 and C677).  On ivory plaque on a teakwood stand.  C676 and C677 are from same boulder of jade.  Probably a wedding gift with meaning of good wishes (ruyi), prosperity (deer) and long life (fungus and pine).
credit_line: Purchased from Wanamaker's Department Store; subscription of Eldridge R. Johnson, 1927

title: Statue
description: Bronze statue of Bodhisattva Shadakshari Lokesvara.  Figure has four arms, two hands are held together in namaskara mudra and the other two hands are raised at shoulder height, the right one holding a chain with pendant.  Figure is seated in dhyanasana on a lotus throne and wears flowing robes and scarves as well as clear, red and green glass inlaid jewellry including her crown.  Above her crown another smaller head protrudes from the hair.  Figure is gold colored with blue hair.
credit_line: Gift of the Estate of Fred Maloof (Richard G. and Jennifer L. Maloof), 1994

title: Medicine
creator: Unknown
description: 大楓子. Lucraban seeds (imported from Thailand). They are nearly an inch long, consisting of a hard woody outer shell, to whose surface the pulp or rind adheres. The oily albumen incloses heart-shaped leafy cotyledons. Cure for leprosy. The powdered oily nucleus of the seed is administered in doses of a drachm twice a day for four months and the expressed oil occasionally rubbed on the skin. From Singapore and Penang. Value at Ningbo, $9 per picul. Dark seeds. One of a collection of samples of Chinese medicine, each in an individual glass jar sealed with cork top.
credit_line: Gift of R. Stewart Culin, pre-1903

title: Rubbing
description: Ink-squeeze rubbing taken from a stone stele engraved with a portrait of Confucius. This is one of the most frequently reproduced images of Confucius, and exists in several versions. An inscription on the stele, reproduced in the rubbing, indicates that the image derives from a painting by the Tang artist Wu Daozi 吳道子, active in the early 8th c. No original by this artist survives, however, so the origin of this image in the works of Wu Daozi cannot be confirmed. The stele from which this rubbing was taken is perhaps one in the Confucius Temple in Qufu 曲阜, Shandong. The image bears four inscribed lines of four characters extolling Confucius’ virtues. These are taken from the “Eulogy of Confucius (孔子讚)” by Chen Fengwu 陳鳳梧 (1475-1541).
credit_line: Museum Purchase, 1929

title: Riding Whip
description: Chieftain's riding whip.  Lacquered wood and brass; braided leather thong and wrist loop.
credit_line: Gift of Mrs. Robert R. Service, 1951

title: Wine Jug
description: Wine jug.  Copper with green patina.  High ring base, globular body, shoulder sloping to very short neck;  wider mouth with vertical rim.  Two holes in base suggest it was intended to be carried with sling strap.  Relief decoration on body:  Four sacred patterns, only two of which are decipherable - swastika and three jewels; another may be intended for vajras.
credit_line: Gift of Mrs. Robert R. Service, 1951

title: Case
description: Case of yak hide bound in silver studded with false corals and turquoise; extra ring to prevent knife slipping.  Original catalogue has "woman's" but women don't use knives; probably boy's.
credit_line: Gift of Mrs. Robert R. Service, 1951

title: Pen Case
description: Pen case.  Silver over brass.  Pierced work; obverse, 3 dragons; reverse, 8 Buddhist symbols.
credit_line: Gift of Mrs. Robert R. Service, 1951

title: Wine Jar
description: Wine jar.  Cast copper.  Low foot, ovoid-shaped body, shoulder sloping to short vertical neck; heavy, wider, vertical rim.  Relief decoration; cloud collar pattern including band of wavemotif above 8 Buddhist symbols.  Very fine workmanship.
credit_line: Gift of Mrs. Robert R. Service, 1951

title: Snuff Horn
description: Polished white yak horn with brass and silver mounting; copper pin attached by thong.
credit_line: Gift of Mrs. Robert R. Service, 1951

title: Wine Jar
description: Wine jar.  Cast brass.  Very low foot; globular body, the sides expanding slightly to rounded shoulder; short, vertical neck; wider mouth with vertical rim.  Decoration;  inverted 6 lobed cloud collar on body below six of the eight buddhist symbols in medallions.
credit_line: Gift of Mrs. Robert R. Service, 1951

title: Pen Case
description: Silver gilt pen case.  Relief decoration; obverse, single dragon in rinceau; reverse, 8 Buddhist symbols imposed on rinceau.
credit_line: Gift of Mrs. Robert R. Service, 1951

title: Strike-A-Light
description: Strike-a-light.  Opens at top with strong spring instead of at bottom.  Each side copper with frame(double on bottom) of brass studs around openwork section.  Unusual brass trimming; chasing on steel.
credit_line: Gift of Mrs. Robert R. Service, 1951

title: Sheath
description: Sheath, with slightly upturned end, covered with brass except for wide sharksin band.  Relief decoration of dragon and phoenix.  Filligree design on sheath with back sottered on.  Various degrees of workmanship.
credit_line: Gift of Mrs. Robert R. Service, 1951

title: Tea Brewing Cauldron
description: Large cauldron.  Copper.  Rounded base, vertical sides with narrow flange at middle; high, outturned rim with incurved edge.  Decoration:  8 Buddhist symbols shown in peculiar way:  3 panels of 2 symbols each in high relief, 2 panels of 1 symbol each in very low relief.  For brewing buttered tea.
credit_line: Gift of Mrs. Robert R. Service, 1951

title: Short Sword
description: Short sword.  Steel and iron blade.  Plain quatrefoil brass inverted cup guard.  Simple wood handle; with fine brass and copper lines on iron hilt above and below a row of piercings(for jewels?).  Blade is worn down to smaller size.  Feels like older piece.
credit_line: Gift of Mrs. Robert R. Service, 1951

title: Pen Case
description: Silver gilt pen case.  Relief decoration; obverse, single dragon in rinceau; reverse, 8 Buddhist symbols imposed on rinceau.
credit_line: Gift of Mrs. Robert R. Service, 1951

title: Scabbard
description: Sheat of cloth covered wood;  single piece iron binding beautifully worked with gold tendrils and holding one large silver stud; retained on obverse between binding is an inset of silver repousee in four panels separated by three immense false corals.  Panel and binding of silver repousee at open end.
credit_line: Gift of Mrs. Robert R. Service, 1951

title: Cartoon
culture: Tibetan | Tibetan Buddhism | Lamaism | Gelupgpa Sect
description: Cartoons or pounces for Lama Paintings to direct the artist.  Paper.  Tsongkhapa with the lineage of the Dalai lamas on one side and the lineage of the Panchen lamas on the other--all are Yellow Lama Sect (Gelupgspa).
credit_line: Gift of Lawrence Sickman, 1953

title: Statuette
description: Brass statuette of a cow reclining on a platform.  Platform missing one foot.  Cow facing candle stick and holder-type stand.  This is a nandi, vehicle of the god Shiva.  This is probably a pilgrim's souvenir brought home after visiting a shrine.
credit_line: Gift of Jesse H. Holmes, Jr., 1973

title: Tsamba Box
description: One of a nested set of Tsamba boxes.  For holding barley flour (Tsamba), salt and condiments.  Wood with floral patterns in black on lustrous copper varnish. This principal vessel has a has low conical foot, sub-globular body, groove below short inset neck with rather wide mouth.  Fitting into the neck is a box like vessel.
credit_line: Gift of Mrs. Robert R. Service, 1951

title: Chopstick
credit_line: Gift of Mrs. Robert R. Service, 1951

title: Knife
description: Knife.  Single-edged iron blade, its end extended between two flat pieces of bone for handle.  Deeply engraved scroll and lotus decoration on both sides of blade.  Scroll design on silver end of handle.
credit_line: Gift of Mrs. Robert R. Service, 1951

title: Drum
description: Drum (Damaru).  Same type as 51-4-53.  Skin heads are painted green. Wood is lacquered red with a band on each section of white and black painted masks.  Fragments of red cloth binder and carrying cord ornamented with shell discs.
credit_line: Gift of Mrs. Robert R. Service, 1951

title: Lid
credit_line: Purchased from Alexander Scott, 1914

title: Dagger Sheath
description: Scabbard for dagger (A1103A).  Shark skin grip on the handle.  Tibetan hilt form.  Leather band on the scabbard.  Bhutanese type scabbard.  Sheath may have been made at a different time than blade.
credit_line: Purchased from W. O. Oldman, 1911

title: Wine Cup
description: Small wine cup.  Used on Buddhist alters to hold "butter" (Ghee) with a wick inserted and lit to function as a lamp.  Teak and silver lined.  Probably modern imitation of Chinese porcelain wine cup.  Low shallow foot with rolled rim.
credit_line: Gift of Mrs. Robert R. Service, 1951

title: Table Setting Case
materials: Bamboo | Shark Skin (uncertain) | Ray Skin (uncertain) | Ivory | Copper Alloy
description: Case for table set.
credit_line: Gift of the Academy of Natural Sciences of Philadelphia, 1997

title: Gem
description: Sommerville: Black Jade: Stag and Doe. Carved black jade plaque with figures of deer buck and doe surrounded by trees.  Chinese, Case LL.
credit_line: Bequest of Maxwell Sommerville, 1904

title: Fan
description: Circular fan.  Grey silk; embroidered in bright colors in satin stitch with six applique figures;  the two sides are identical.  Black laquer frmae and handle with gold lacquer ornamentation.
credit_line: Gift of Laura Bell, 1940

title: Stand
creator: Huang Yuan Tsao
description: Chuk tan. Pewter stand for candle (one of a pair). Oblong.  Company name Huang Yuan Tsao.  Same shape as 15405, but a little larger.
credit_line: Gift of Dr. W. W. McClure, 1892

title: Box
description: Black laquer box containing chinese ink pieces of various shapes and sizes. Lid of box decorated with gold and red dragon.
credit_line: Gift of P. S. Wong through University of Pennsylvania Archives, 1973

title: Drum
description: Black lacquered body with parchment heads, small nails, and three metal rings.  On each drum head is a black insignia.  Loose beater inside each head.
credit_line: Gift of the Philadelphia Museum of Art, 1951

title: Drum
description: Pang-ku, drum.  For temple services.   Shallow wood frame drum. Skin on one side only, lacquered with red, green, and blue design. Attached with double row of studs. Leather handle.
credit_line: Gift of Mrs. Sarah (William D.) Frishmuth, 1900

title: Model
description: White marble flower pot with 2 long copper stems extending from it. Blue (paint chipping) leaves. Small loosely attached red/orange beads as flower buds.
credit_line: Gift of the Estate of Fred Maloof (Richard G. and Jennifer L. Maloof), 1994

title: Trumpet
description: Kati-ti or Sona (Heang Teih)  Diamond shaped conical wood tube, fluted in profile. 7 frontal finger holes, 1 hole at back.  Brass bell. Brass mouthpiece: stem, disc, 2  bulges, disc.
credit_line: Gift of the Philadelphia Museum of Art, 1951

title: Pot
description: Round white marble pot. 2 copper flowers extending from it. Long blue leaves and numerous small red/orange beads for flower buds (coral?). Blue paint chipping off leaves and some beads loose.
credit_line: Gift of the Estate of Fred Maloof (Richard G. and Jennifer L. Maloof), 1994

title: Statue
description: Seated praying monk with flowing light green robes. Hands held with palms together. Removable string of beads: 18 black & 1 red with tassel around hands. Brown skin, 2 white teeth, bald. Location: 3rd tier center on pillow.
credit_line: Gift of the Estate of Fred Maloof (Richard G. and Jennifer L. Maloof), 1994

title: Drum
description: Po-fou, drum.  One of two (A852A-B).  Barrel drums for Confucian ceremony.  Larger of the two.  Wooden painted red with white lettering.  Parchment heads with painted design.  One row of nails per head.  Two metal rings.
credit_line: Gift of Mrs. Sarah (William D.) Frishmuth, 1900

title: Drum
description: One of two drums.  Ping-ku.  "Flat drums."  Used in theaters to mark time.  Red wooden frame; 2 skin heads with large nails holding them in place.  2 metal rings, one on each side.  Inscription on one side.  One head is completely split.
credit_line: Gift of Mrs. Sarah (William D.) Frishmuth, 1900

title: Bowl
description: Shallow bowl with outturned rim set on disc base.  Teak lined in silver, graduating in size.  Used in Buddhist altars to hold 'butter' (Ghee) with a wick inserted and lit to function as a lamp.
credit_line: Academy of Natural Science / University Museum Expedition to Southwest China and Tibet; Gordon T. Bowles, 1932

title: Model
description: Small gate for shrine. Top: green carved design ivory. Bottom: wood inlaid with mother-of-pearl on front side. Thin, dark strips of wood attached to top and bottom. Notches to attach gate to shrine. Location: 3rd tier, right front gate inserts into frame.
credit_line: Gift of the Estate of Fred Maloof (Richard G. and Jennifer L. Maloof), 1994

title: Prayer Beads
description: Wooden disks separated by large carnelian beads: three long pendant strings of copper beads terminating in a disc.  3 short pendants of glass and carnelian bedas, one terminating in a brass cylinder [GMB 1939]  Prototype of Mandarin chain [SVRC 1955]
credit_line: Academy of Natural Science / University Museum Expedition to Southwest China and Tibet; Gordon T. Bowles, 1932

title: Folding Fan
description: Ivory folding fan.  All over design of human figures with houses and foliage.  While each spoke is a separate unit, the grouping of the center spokes from a pattern.  End spokes with human figures on balconies andunder flowering trees, with a conventionalized floral register below, all in very high relief.
credit_line: Purchased from S. Krauss, 1912

title: Guitar
description: Double snakeskin headed body of dark brown wood. Metal rim between head and body long dark wood neck and head curved into scroll at end. Ivory nut tied on.  Three tapering hexagonal pegs, one missing.  No strings attached. Thickness of head 7cm. Poor condition, head detached from neck, snakeskin split.
credit_line: Gift of the Academy of Natural Sciences of Philadelphia, 1997

title: Gong
description: So-bo, gong.  Metal gong for temple used to call guests to dinner. Brass, circular with rim turned over for 5 cm, depressed band around edge, raised boss in center. Hung from stand by cord (not original) through two holes in rim. In Beijing this gong is called T'ung Ku. Good condition. With drum stand (A856B).
credit_line: Gift of Mrs. Sarah (William D.) Frishmuth, 1900

title: Vase
description: Chinese cloisonne enamel vase. Bulbous pyriform body fashioned after a Han Dynasty bronze prototype. It has an attenuated neck and two mask like handles with loose rings. The cloisonne embellishment presents a turquoise blue ground color filled with conventional lotus flowers, picked out in rich red, amber yellow, and emerald green, together with white and crushed Chinese ruby enamels. The shoulder and neck is encircled, like the base, with dark lapis blue bands that enclose small colored blossoms; whilst the upper section with turquoise blue ground displays fringe-like ornaments and pendants.
credit_line: Purchased from C. T. Loo, 1916

title: Mortuary Figurine
description: Funerary figurine of a painted pottery horse with its head curved down. This horse would have been placed in tombs with other objects that were important to take into the afterlife. The Bactrian horse, depicted here, with slender legs and a massive body, was imported from the greater Iran area. Replacing the small and stocky Mongolian breeds, the Bactrian became the favorite among royalty. There were likely harnesses and riding gear in the figures' original state, along with real horsehair for the mane and tail. C694 and C695 are a pair.
credit_line: Purchased from C. T. Loo, 1928

title: Mortuary Figurine
description: Funerary figurine of a painted pottery horse with its head up. This horse would have been placed in tombs with other objects that were important to take into the afterlife. The Bactrian horse, depicted here, with slender legs and a massive body, was imported from the greater Iran area. Replacing the small and stocky Mongolian breeds, the Bactrian became the favorite among royalty. There were likely harnesses and riding gear in the figures' original state, along with real horsehair for the mane and tail.  C694 and C695 are a pair.
credit_line: Purchased from C. T. Loo, 1928

title: Zither
description: Se. Used chiefly at imperial and religious ceremonies. Large, wooden, rectangular, box-like body, the top of which is arched. Bottom flat with large circular holes at both ends, one end of body slants back from otherwise flat shape, hollow interior, two bridges extend across arched top; one where one end starts to slant away from main body, the other 20 cm. from end of lute. Wood piece and two bridges are made of dark wood, the rest is painted black with gold designs of flowers, birds, and a dragon on top. Twenty five strings extend across the main sound board. Good condition. Crack on top, most of strings present but broken.  Wooden "bow" accompanying - brown wood, tip broken.
credit_line: Gift of Mrs. Sarah (William D.) Frishmuth, 1900

title: Rubbing
description: Ink-squeeze rubbing taken from a stone stele engraved with a portrait of Confucius. This is one of the most frequently reproduced images of Confucius, and exists in several versions. An inscription on the stele, reproduced in the rubbing, indicates that the image derives from a painting by the Tang artist Wu Daozi 吳道子, active in the early 8th c. No original by this artist survives, however, so the origin of this image in the works of Wu Daozi cannot be confirmed. The stele from which this rubbing was taken is perhaps one in the Confucius Temple in Qufu 曲阜, Shandong. The image bears the inscribed title, “Portrait of the First Teacher, Confucius, Propagating his Teachings”, and four lines of four characters extolling Confucius’ virtues. The latter are taken from the “Eulogy of Confucius (孔子讚)” by Chen Fengwu 陳鳳梧 (1475-1541). The stele from which this rubbing was taken is very similar to, but distinct from, the source of rubbing 29-25-22.
credit_line: Museum Purchase, 1929

title: Vase
description: Chinese cloisonne enamel vase (huagu) in two sections. Quadrangular beaker shape with everted base and flaring rim. An early example, fashioned in the form of hieratic ornament after an ancient bronze ritual vessel, prototypes of which are known to date from the Zhou Dynasty. All four sides and corners are buttressed with vertical dentated ribs or aretes (in Chinese fei-chi) of bronze, showing an unusual cham-leve incrusted enamel enrichment.The cloisonne (Chinese: 珐蓝 falan) decoration on the body is composed with ascending leaf motifs that appear on upper and lower sections in green, relieved by scrolling details in varied tones of blue, red and yellow including red color from crushed Chinese rubies. The small middle section on four sides reveals mask-like lineaments of the "dreaded land ogre," (Chinese: 饕餮紋 taotie wen), an ancient hieratic design, introduced assumably as an admonition against gluttonous evils. The lower flanges of the base uniformly sustain archaic cloisonne bird headed scrolls, and the turquoise blue interior involves lotus flowers amid leafy scrolls executed in varied cloisonne enamel colors peculiar to its provenance. This specimen of Chinese 景泰蓝 "Jingtailan" may be characterized as most notable for its inimitable colors, among which may be seen typical lapis lazuli and turquoise blue tones, varied greens, red, and yellow. It dates to the era of Emperor Jingtai (景泰) of the Ming Dynasty (1449 - 1456 CE).
credit_line: Purchased from Worch of Paris, 1914

title: Cartoon
culture: Tibetan | Tibetan Buddhism | Lamaism | Gelupgpa Sect
description: Cartoons or pounces for Lama Paintings to direct the artist.  Paper.  Goddess Lhamo, Yama and Mahakala.
credit_line: Gift of Lawrence Sickman, 1953

title: Bowl
description: Wood lacquered in lotus designs in red, black, and orange. Slightly concave base, rounded sides; pierced lug below rim.
credit_line: Gift of Mrs. Robert R. Service, 1951

title: Pen Case
description: Pen case.  Iron, gilded.  Cylindrical.  Pierced decoration of dragons climbing up tendrils;  occasional lotus.  Work of the city of Derge.
credit_line: Gift of Mrs. Robert R. Service, 1951

title: Short Sword
description: Short sword.  Knife has single edged steel blade with prominent blood gutters; blade edge worn jagged.  Quatrefoil iron inverted cup guard below hilt which is in three wide bands -- iron with loops of vertical grooving, sharksin, 4-part iron ornament, each part divided into two vertical panels of relief decoration.  Engraved handle.  Various degrees of workmanship.
credit_line: Gift of Mrs. Robert R. Service, 1951

title: Jug
description: Large jug.  Cast copper.  High foot sloping to body whose straight sides expand to high rounded shoulder;  neck with nearly vertical sides; large mouth with large pouring spout.  Heavy strap handle.  Small cylindrical spout from body below base of handle.  Rather plain except for band of flowers in full round around top; conventionalized jewel band on handle and conventional lion on top of handle.
credit_line: Gift of Mrs. Robert R. Service, 1951

title: Pen Case
description: Pen case.  Silver over brass.  Pierced work; obverse, 3 dragons; reverse, 8 Buddhist symbols.
credit_line: Gift of Mrs. Robert R. Service, 1951

title: Cartoon
culture: Tibetan | Tibetan Buddhism | Lamaism | Gelupgpa Sect | Buddhist
description: Cartoon for Lama Buddhist painting of Tsongkhapa, Founder of the Yellow Sect.  Free hand drawing.  Very fragile.
credit_line: Gift of Lawrence Sickman, 1952

title: Statuette
description: Statuette.  Large.  Gilt bronze.  Vajradhara (an Adi Buddha) seated holding two thunderbolts in his crossed hands.  On a high dias.  High halo.
credit_line: Purchased from George Lagai, Kny-Sheerer & Company, 1913

title: Statuette
description: Gilt bronze statuette of Maha Matri or Prajnaparamita.  Four armed.  On a lotus.  Inscribed.  No halo.
credit_line: Purchased from Alexander Scott, 1914

title: Cartoon
culture: Tibetan | Tibetan Buddhism | Lamaism | Gelupgpa Sect | Buddhist
description: Cartoons or pounces for Lama Paintings to direct the artist.  Paper.  The Paradise of Amitabha.

title: Pen Case
description: Pen case.  Iron, gilded.  Cylindrical.  Pierced decoration of dragons climbing up tendrils;  occasional lotus.  Work of the city of Derge.
credit_line: Gift of Mrs. Robert R. Service, 1951

title: Teapot Lid
description: Lid for teapot copper trimmed with brass and jewels(coral and turquoise).  Shape similar to 51-4-94, etc.  with unusual monster spout and dragon handle; heavy lotus base.  On each side of body is a gilded plaque with a folk-lore Mang dragon, said to be from Chinese armor.  Plain stepped lid with rounded lower section and with knob.
credit_line: Gift of Mrs. Robert R. Service, 1951

title: Hat
description: Head ornament.  Worn on back of head by chieftain's wife.  Top:  double crescent-shaped charm box-gold plaited with designs in gold filigree inset with corals and turquoise.  Second row:  Rectangular silver plaque with two peacocks(plumes in head and eyes) in relief;  inset with turquoise and false coral(some missing).  Lower row:  2 lotuses; rectangular.  Silk tassels.  In three sections; joined by long necklace of coral beads.
credit_line: Gift of Mrs. Robert R. Service, 1951

title: Statue
description: Duck or goose shaped vessel.  Circular and floral gold and silver inlay.  Hole at top of bird's back and spout at mouth.
credit_line: Purchased from Spink & Son, 1914

title: Fan
description: Folding ivory fan, painted linen.  Faces of the figures are of ivory.
credit_line: Gift of Mrs. Theron I. Crane, 1928

title: Panel
description: Wooden panel fragment with cloth which is part of a larger shrine.
credit_line: Gift of the Estate of Fred Maloof (Richard G. and Jennifer L. Maloof), 1994

title: Inkstand
description: Gilt bronze ink stand or incense holder.  The lotus flower design seems to indicate its religious use.
credit_line: Purchased from Viginier of Paris; Avery Fund, 1924

title: Box
description: Round. Relief decoration: animal and floral. For seal wax.
credit_line: Gift of Elise Biddle (Mrs. Harald) Paumgarten, 1948, 1948

title: Rubbing
description: Rubbing of a stela with a poem by Buddhist monk Huixiu.  There are eighteen different types of charachters including calligraphy by Buddhist monk Mengying.
